5.25.text:
It was a bright cold day in April, and the
clocks were striking thirteen. Winston Smith,

11.85.text:
his chin nuzzled into his breast in an effort
to escape the vile wind, slipped quickly through

16.83.text:
the glass doors of Victory Mansions, though
not quickly enough to prevent a swirl of gritty

21.62.text: dust from entering along with him.

24.79.text:
The hallway smelt of boiled cabbage and old
rag mats. At one end of it a coloured poster,

30.61.text:
too large for indoor display, had been tacked
to the wall. It depicted simply an enormous

35.51.text:
face, more than a metre wide: the face of
a man of about forty-five, with a heavy black

40.97.text:
moustache and ruggedly handsome features.
Winston made for the stairs. It was no use

46.54.text:
trying the lift. Even at the best of times
it was seldom working, and at present the

50.39.text:
electric current was cut off during daylight
hours. It was part of the economy drive in

55.07.text:
preparation for Hate Week. The flat was seven
flights up, and Winston, who was thirty-nine

60.91.text:
and had a varicose ulcer above his right ankle,
went slowly, resting several times on the

65.92.text:
way. On each landing, opposite the lift-shaft,
the poster with the enormous face gazed from

72.78.text:
the wall. It was one of those pictures which
are so contrived that the eyes follow you

76.35.text:
about when you move. BIG BROTHER IS WATCHING
YOU, the caption beneath it ran.

83.37.text:
Inside the flat a fruity voice was reading
out a list of figures which had something

86.84.text:
to do with the production of pig-iron. The
voice came from an oblong metal plaque like

92.23.text:
a dulled mirror which formed part of the surface
of the right-hand wall. Winston turned a switch

97.98.text:
and the voice sank somewhat, though the words
were still distinguishable. The instrument

103.13.text:
(the telescreen, it was called) could be dimmed,
but there was no way of shutting it off completely.

107.80.text:
He moved over to the window: a smallish, frail
figure, the meagreness of his body merely

113.27.text:
emphasized by the blue overalls which were
the uniform of the party. His hair was very

119.31.text:
fair, his face naturally sanguine, his skin
roughened by coarse soap and blunt razor blades

124.50.text: and the cold of the winter that had just ended.

127.81.text:
Outside, even through the shut window-pane,
the world looked cold. Down in the street

133.56.text:
little eddies of wind were whirling dust and
torn paper into spirals, and though the sun

138.35.text:
was shining and the sky a harsh blue, there
seemed to be no colour in anything, except

142.88.text:
the posters that were plastered everywhere.
The blackmoustachio'd face gazed down from

147.90.text:
every commanding corner. There was one on
the house-front immediately opposite. BIG

152.99.text:
BROTHER IS WATCHING YOU, the caption said,
while the dark eyes looked deep into Winston's

158.46.text:
own. Down at street level another poster,
torn at one corner, flapped fitfully in the

163.89.text:
wind, alternately covering and uncovering
the single word INGSOC. In the far distance

170.11.text:
a helicopter skimmed down between the roofs,
hovered for an instant like a bluebottle,

175.04.text:
and darted away again with a curving flight.
It was the police patrol, snooping into people's

180.04.text:
windows. The patrols did not matter, however.
Only the Thought Police mattered.

187.05.text:
Behind Winston's back the voice from the telescreen
was still babbling away about pig-iron and

191.01.text:
the overfulfilment of the Ninth Three-Year
Plan. The telescreen received and transmitted

197.53.text:
simultaneously. Any sound that Winston made,
above the level of a very low whisper, would

201.36.text:
be picked up by it, moreover, so long as he
remained within the field of vision which

205.92.text:
the metal plaque commanded, he could be seen
as well as heard. There was of course no way

210.79.text:
of knowing whether you were being watched
at any given moment. How often, or on what

217.03.text:
system, the Thought Police plugged in on any
individual wire was guesswork. It was even

221.68.text:
conceivable that they watched everybody all
the time. But at any rate they could plug

226.72.text:
in your wire whenever they wanted to. You
had to live — did live, from habit that

233.04.text:
became instinct — in the assumption that
every sound you made was overheard, and, except

242.50.text:
Winston kept his back turned to the telescreen.
It was safer, though, as he well knew, even

247.30.text:
a back can be revealing. A kilometre away
the Ministry of Truth, his place of work,

252.32.text:
towered vast and white above the grimy landscape.
This, he thought with a sort of vague distaste

259.38.text:
— this was London, chief city of Airstrip
One, itself the third most populous of the

264.80.text:
provinces of Oceania. He tried to squeeze
out some childhood memory that should tell

270.18.text:
him whether London had always been quite like
this. Were there always these vistas of rotting

275.14.text:
nineteenth-century houses, their sides shored
up with baulks of timber, their windows patched

280.11.text:
with cardboard and their roofs with corrugated
iron, their crazy garden walls sagging in

285.25.text:
all directions? And the bombed sites where
the plaster dust swirled in the air and the

290.28.text:
willow-herb straggled over the heaps of rubble;
and the places where the bombs had cleared

294.51.text:
a larger patch and there had sprung up sordid
colonies of wooden dwellings like chicken-houses?

298.86.text:
But it was no use, he could not remember:
nothing remained of his childhood except a

305.34.text:
series of bright-lit tableaux occurring against
no background and mostly unintelligible.

312.42.text:
The Ministry of Truth — Minitrue, in Newspeak(1)
— was startlingly different from any other

317.74.text:
object in sight. It was an enormous pyramidal
structure of glittering white concrete, soaring

323.89.text:
up, terrace after terrace, 300 metres into
the air. From where Winston stood it was just

329.23.text:
possible to read, picked out on its white
face in elegant lettering, the three slogans

335.38.text:
WAR IS PEACE
FREEDOM IS SLAVERY

342.12.text:
The Ministry of Truth contained, it was said,
three thousand rooms above ground level, and

347.26.text:
corresponding ramifications below. Scattered
about London there were just three other buildings

353.38.text:
of similar appearance and size. So completely
did they dwarf the surrounding architecture

358.50.text:
that from the roof of Victory Mansions you
could see all four of them simultaneously.

364.00.text:
They were the homes of the four Ministries
between which the entire apparatus of government

368.16.text:
was divided. The Ministry of Truth, which
concerned itself with news, entertainment,

373.19.text:
education, and the fine arts. The Ministry
of Peace, which concerned itself with war.

378.13.text:
The Ministry of Love, which maintained law
and order. And the Ministry of Plenty, which

382.71.text:
was responsible for economic affairs. Their
names, in Newspeak: Minitrue, Minipax, Miniluv,

390.57.text:
The Ministry of Love was the really frightening
one. There were no windows in it at all. Winston

397.35.text:
had never been inside the Ministry of Love,
nor within half a kilometre of it. It was

401.86.text:
a place impossible to enter except on official
business, and then only by penetrating through

406.37.text:
a maze of barbed-wire entanglements, steel
doors, and hidden machine-gun nests. Even

412.68.text:
the streets leading up to its outer barriers
were roamed by gorilla-faced guards in black

421.34.text:
Winston turned round abruptly. He had set
his features into the expression of quiet

425.53.text:
optimism which it was advisable to wear when
facing the telescreen. He crossed the room

430.24.text:
into the tiny kitchen. By leaving the Ministry
at this time of day he had sacrificed his

434.82.text:
lunch in the canteen, and he was aware that
there was no food in the kitchen except a

438.98.text:
hunk of dark-coloured bread which had got
to be saved for tomorrow's breakfast. He took

444.32.text:
down from the shelf a bottle of colourless
liquid with a plain white label marked VICTORY

448.95.text:
GIN. It gave off a sickly, oily smell, as
of Chinese rice-spirit. Winston poured out

455.67.text:
nearly a teacupful, nerved himself for a shock,
and gulped it down like a dose of medicine.

461.12.text:
Instantly his face turned scarlet and the
water ran out of his eyes. The stuff was like

465.12.text:
nitric acid, and moreover, in swallowing it
one had the sensation of being hit on the

469.75.text:
back of the head with a rubber club. The next
moment, however, the burning in his belly

474.30.text:
died down and the world began to look more
cheerful. He took a cigarette from a crumpled

480.43.text:
packet marked VICTORY CIGARETTES and incautiously
held it upright, whereupon the tobacco fell

485.67.text:
out on to the floor. With the next he was
more successful. He went back to the living-room

492.02.text:
and sat down at a small table that stood to
the left of the telescreen. From the table

496.74.text:
drawer he took out a penholder, a bottle of
ink, and a thick, quarto-sized blank book

501.59.text: with a red back and a marbled cover.

504.83.text:
For some reason the telescreen in the living-room
was in an unusual position. Instead of being

509.59.text:
placed, as was normal, in the end wall, where
it could command the whole room, it was in

513.96.text:
the longer wall, opposite the window. To one
side of it there was a shallow alcove in which

519.07.text:
Winston was now sitting, and which, when the
flats were built, had probably been intended

522.67.text:
to hold bookshelves. By sitting in the alcove,
and keeping well back, Winston was able to

528.60.text:
remain outside the range of the telescreen,
so far as sight went. He could be heard, of

534.20.text:
course, but so long as he stayed in his present
position he could not be seen. It was partly

539.47.text:
the unusual geography of the room that had
suggested to him the thing that he was now

545.78.text:
But it had also been suggested by the book
that he had just taken out of the drawer.

549.49.text:
It was a peculiarly beautiful book. Its smooth
creamy paper, a little yellowed by age, was

556.03.text:
of a kind that had not been manufactured for
at least forty years past. He could guess,

561.05.text:
however, that the book was much older than
that. He had seen it lying in the window of

565.03.text:
a frowsy little junk-shop in a slummy quarter
of the town (just what quarter he did not

569.82.text:
now remember) and had been stricken immediately
by an overwhelming desire to possess it. Party

576.19.text:
members were supposed not to go into ordinary
shops ('dealing on the free market', it was

580.54.text:
called), but the rule was not strictly kept,
because there were various things, such as

585.20.text:
shoelaces and razor blades, which it was impossible
to get hold of in any other way. He had given

591.07.text:
a quick glance up and down the street and
then had slipped inside and bought the book

594.98.text:
for two dollars fifty. At the time he was
not conscious of wanting it for any particular

600.00.text:
purpose. He had carried it guiltily home in
his briefcase. Even with nothing written in

605.18.text: it, it was a compromising possession.

608.31.text:
The thing that he was about to do was to open
a diary. This was not illegal (nothing was

613.97.text:
illegal, since there were no longer any laws),
but if detected it was reasonably certain

618.79.text:
that it would be punished by death, or at
least by twenty-five years in a forced-labour

623.04.text:
camp. Winston fitted a nib into the penholder
and sucked it to get the grease off. The pen

629.32.text:
was an archaic instrument, seldom used even
for signatures, and he had procured one, furtively

634.70.text:
and with some difficulty, simply because of
a feeling that the beautiful creamy paper

638.93.text:
deserved to be written on with a real nib
instead of being scratched with an ink-pencil.

645.00.text:
Actually he was not used to writing by hand.
Apart from very short notes, it was usual

648.91.text:
to dictate everything into the speak-write
which was of course impossible for his present

653.31.text:
purpose. He dipped the pen into the ink and
then faltered for just a second. A tremor

660.16.text:
had gone through his bowels. To mark the paper
was the decisive act. In small clumsy letters

671.51.text:
He sat back. A sense of complete helplessness
had descended upon him. To begin with, he

679.64.text:
did not know with any certainty that this
was 1984. It must be round about that date,

685.34.text:
since he was fairly sure that his age was
thirty-nine, and he believed that he had been

689.38.text:
born in 1944 or 1945; but it was never possible
nowadays to pin down any date within a year

696.04.text:
For whom, it suddenly occurred to him to wonder,
was he writing this diary? For the future,

703.75.text:
for the unborn. His mind hovered for a moment
round the doubtful date on the page, and then

710.31.text:
fetched up with a bump against the Newspeak
word doublethink. For the first time the magnitude

715.76.text:
of what he had undertaken came home to him.
How could you communicate with the future?

720.71.text:
It was of its nature impossible. Either the
future would resemble the present, in which

725.60.text:
case it would not listen to him: or it would
be different from it, and his predicament

731.27.text:
For some time he sat gazing stupidly at the
paper. The telescreen had changed over to

737.24.text:
strident military music. It was curious that
he seemed not merely to have lost the power

742.36.text:
of expressing himself, but even to have forgotten
what it was that he had originally intended

747.19.text:
to say. For weeks past he had been making
ready for this moment, and it had never crossed

753.75.text:
his mind that anything would be needed except
courage. The actual writing would be easy.

758.85.text:
All he had to do was to transfer to paper
the interminable restless monologue that had

762.76.text:
been running inside his head, literally for
years. At this moment, however, even the monologue

768.29.text:
had dried up. Moreover his varicose ulcer
had begun itching unbearably. He dared not

773.87.text:
scratch it, because if he did so it always
became inflamed. The seconds were ticking

778.76.text:
by. He was conscious of nothing except the
blankness of the page in front of him, the

783.20.text:
itching of the skin above his ankle, the blaring
of the music, and a slight booziness caused

789.99.text:
Suddenly he began writing in sheer panic,
only imperfectly aware of what he was setting

793.72.text:
down. His small but childish handwriting straggled
up and down the page, shedding first its capital

799.18.text: letters and finally even its full stops:

802.45.text:
April 4th, 1984. Last night to the flicks.
All war films. One very good one of a ship

810.47.text:
full of refugees being bombed somewhere in
the Mediterranean. Audience much amused by

815.43.text:
shots of a great huge fat man trying to swim
away with a helicopter after him, first you

820.39.text:
saw him wallowing along in the water like
a porpoise, then you saw him through the helicopters

824.94.text:
gunsights, then he was full of holes and the
sea round him turned pink and he sank as suddenly

829.50.text:
as though the holes had let in the water,
audience shouting with laughter when he sank.

834.50.text:
then you saw a lifeboat full of children with
a helicopter hovering over it. there was a

838.69.text:
middle-aged woman might have been a jewess
sitting up in the bow with a little boy about

842.49.text:
three years old in her arms. little boy screaming
with fright and hiding his head between her

847.17.text:
breasts as if he was trying to burrow right
into her and the woman putting her arms round

851.54.text:
him and comforting him although she was blue
with fright herself, all the time covering

856.40.text:
him up as much as possible as if she thought
her arms could keep the bullets off him. then

861.02.text:
the helicopter planted a 20 kilo bomb in among
them terrific flash and the boat went all

866.06.text:
to matchwood. then there was a wonderful shot
of a child's arm going up up up right up into

871.59.text:
the air a helicopter with a camera in its
nose must have followed it up and there was

875.29.text:
a lot of applause from the party seats but
a woman down in the prole part of the house

879.71.text:
suddenly started kicking up a fuss and shouting
they didnt oughter of showed it not in front

883.90.text:
of kids they didnt it aint right not in front
of kids it aint until the police turned her

888.41.text:
turned her out i dont suppose anything happened
to her nobody cares what the proles say typical

895.64.text:
Winston stopped writing, partly because he
was suffering from cramp. He did not know

900.73.text:
what had made him pour out this stream of
rubbish. But the curious thing was that while

905.90.text:
he was doing so a totally different memory
had clarified itself in his mind, to the point

910.95.text:
where he almost felt equal to writing it down.
It was, he now realized, because of this other

915.89.text:
incident that he had suddenly decided to come
home and begin the diary today.

921.73.text:
It had happened that morning at the Ministry,
if anything so nebulous could be said to happen.

927.17.text:
It was nearly eleven hundred, and in the Records
Department, where Winston worked, they were

931.67.text:
dragging the chairs out of the cubicles and
grouping them in the centre of the hall opposite

935.54.text:
the big telescreen, in preparation for the
Two Minutes Hate. Winston was just taking

940.43.text:
his place in one of the middle rows when two
people whom he knew by sight, but had never

944.54.text:
spoken to, came unexpectedly into the room.
One of them was a girl whom he often passed

949.79.text:
in the corridors. He did not know her name,
but he knew that she worked in the Fiction

955.51.text:
Department. Presumably — since he had sometimes
seen her with oily hands and carrying a spanner

960.70.text:
— she had some mechanical job on one of
the novel-writing machines. She was a bold-looking

966.23.text:
girl, of about twenty-seven, with thick hair,
a freckled face, and swift, athletic movements.

971.44.text:
A narrow scarlet sash, emblem of the Junior
Anti-Sex League, was wound several times round

976.31.text:
the waist of her overalls, just tightly enough
to bring out the shapeliness of her hips.

981.59.text:
Winston had disliked her from the very first
moment of seeing her. He knew the reason.

986.35.text:
It was because of the atmosphere of hockey-fields
and cold baths and community hikes and general

991.24.text:
clean-mindedness which she managed to carry
about with her. He disliked nearly all women,

996.32.text:
and especially the young and pretty ones.
It was always the women, and above all the

1000.16.text:
young ones, who were the most bigoted adherents
of the Party, the swallowers of slogans, the

1004.40.text:
amateur spies and nosers-out of unorthodoxy.
But this particular girl gave him the impression

1010.18.text:
of being more dangerous than most. Once when
they passed in the corridor she gave him a

1015.69.text:
quick sidelong glance which seemed to pierce
right into him and for a moment had filled

1019.84.text:
him with black terror. The idea had even crossed
his mind that she might be an agent of the

1024.36.text:
Thought Police. That, it was true, was very
unlikely. Still, he continued to feel a peculiar

1030.26.text:
uneasiness, which had fear mixed up in it
as well as hostility, whenever she was anywhere

1036.28.text:
The other person was a man named O'Brien,
a member of the Inner Party and holder of

1040.74.text:
some post so important and remote that Winston
had only a dim idea of its nature. A momentary

1048.05.text:
hush passed over the group of people round
the chairs as they saw the black overalls

1052.45.text:
of an Inner Party member approaching. O'Brien
was a large, burly man with a thick neck and

1058.69.text:
a coarse, humorous, brutal face. In spite
of his formidable appearance he had a certain

1063.30.text:
charm of manner. He had a trick of resettling
his spectacles on his nose which was curiously

1068.31.text:
disarming — in some indefinable way, curiously
civilized. It was a gesture which, if anyone

1074.79.text:
had still thought in such terms, might have
recalled an eighteenth-century nobleman offering

1078.82.text:
his snuffbox. Winston had seen O'Brien perhaps
a dozen times in almost as many years. He

1085.91.text:
felt deeply drawn to him, and not solely because
he was intrigued by the contrast between O'Brien's

1091.67.text:
urbane manner and his prize-fighter's physique.
Much more it was because of a secretly held

1097.30.text:
belief — or perhaps not even a belief, merely
a hope — that O'Brien's political orthodoxy

1103.28.text:
was not perfect. Something in his face suggested
it irresistibly. And again, perhaps it was

1109.80.text:
not even unorthodoxy that was written in his
face, but simply intelligence. But at any

1115.55.text:
rate he had the appearance of being a person
that you could talk to if somehow you could

1119.19.text:
cheat the telescreen and get him alone. Winston
had never made the smallest effort to verify

1124.47.text:
this guess: indeed, there was no way of doing
so. At this moment O'Brien glanced at his

1129.36.text:
wrist-watch, saw that it was nearly eleven
hundred, and evidently decided to stay in

1132.98.text:
the Records Department until the Two Minutes
Hate was over. He took a chair in the same

1137.88.text:
row as Winston, a couple of places away. A
small, sandy-haired woman who worked in the

1143.38.text:
next cubicle to Winston was between them.
The girl with dark hair was sitting immediately

1149.69.text:
The next moment a hideous, grinding speech,
as of some monstrous machine running without

1155.31.text:
oil, burst from the big telescreen at the
end of the room. It was a noise that set one's

1160.24.text:
teeth on edge and bristled the hair at the
back of one's neck. The Hate had started.

1167.10.text:
As usual, the face of Emmanuel Goldstein,
the Enemy of the People, had flashed on to

1171.30.text:
the screen. There were hisses here and there
among the audience. The little sandy-haired

1176.07.text:
woman gave a squeak of mingled fear and disgust.
Goldstein was the renegade and backslider

1182.59.text:
who once, long ago (how long ago, nobody quite
remembered), had been one of the leading figures

1187.02.text:
of the Party, almost on a level with Big Brother
himself, and then had engaged in counter-revolutionary

1193.80.text:
activities, had been condemned to death, and
had mysteriously escaped and disappeared.

1199.24.text:
The programmes of the Two Minutes Hate varied
from day to day, but there was none in which

1203.53.text:
Goldstein was not the principal figure. He
was the primal traitor, the earliest defiler

1209.07.text:
of the Party's purity. All subsequent crimes
against the Party, all treacheries, acts of

1214.14.text:
sabotage, heresies, deviations, sprang directly
out of his teaching. Somewhere or other he

1221.67.text:
was still alive and hatching his conspiracies:
perhaps somewhere beyond the sea, under the

1226.01.text:
protection of his foreign paymasters, perhaps
even — so it was occasionally rumoured — in

1236.04.text:
Winston's diaphragm was constricted. He could
never see the face of Goldstein without a

1241.18.text:
painful mixture of emotions. It was a lean
Jewish face, with a great fuzzy aureole of

1246.71.text:
white hair and a small goatee beard — a
clever face, and yet somehow inherently despicable,

1252.80.text:
with a kind of senile silliness in the long
thin nose, near the end of which a pair of

1257.38.text:
spectacles was perched. It resembled the face
of a sheep, and the voice, too, had a sheep-like

1264.19.text:
quality. Goldstein was delivering his usual
venomous attack upon the doctrines of the

1269.88.text:
Party — an attack so exaggerated and perverse
that a child should have been able to see

1273.60.text:
through it, and yet just plausible enough
to fill one with an alarmed feeling that other

1278.82.text:
people, less level-headed than oneself, might
be taken in by it. He was abusing Big Brother,

1284.22.text:
he was denouncing the dictatorship of the
Party, he was demanding the immediate conclusion

1288.41.text:
of peace with Eurasia, he was advocating freedom
of speech, freedom of the Press, freedom of

1293.00.text:
assembly, freedom of thought, he was crying
hysterically that the revolution had been

1297.28.text:
betrayed — and all this in rapid polysyllabic
speech which was a sort of parody of the habitual

1303.03.text:
style of the orators of the Party, and even
contained Newspeak words: more Newspeak words,

1308.22.text:
indeed, than any Party member would normally
use in real life. And all the while, lest

1313.44.text:
one should be in any doubt as to the reality
which Goldstein's specious claptrap covered,

1318.67.text:
behind his head on the telescreen there marched
the endless columns of the Eurasian army — row

1323.56.text:
after row of solid-looking men with expressionless
Asiatic faces, who swam up to the surface

1329.27.text:
of the screen and vanished, to be replaced
by others exactly similar. The dull rhythmic

1335.15.text:
tramp of the soldiers" boots formed the background
to Goldstein's bleating voice.

1341.72.text:
Before the Hate had proceeded for thirty seconds,
uncontrollable exclamations of rage were breaking

1346.47.text:
out from half the people in the room. The
self-satisfied sheep-like face on the screen,

1351.17.text:

WAR IS PEACE

2842.04.text:

2862.31.text:

2868.34.text:

2878.51.text:

2882.19.text:

2887.68.text:

2894.67.text:

2900.11.text:

2907.36.text:

2914.08.text:

2918.33.text:

2923.32.text:

2929.05.text:

2935.05.text:

2941.22.text:

2946.96.text:

It was not by making yourself heard but by

2951.66.text:

2959.74.text:
To the future or to the past, to a time when

2965.17.text:

2973.31.text:

2987.68.text:

2992.96.text:

He wrote:

2997.53.text:
Thoughtcrime does not entail death: thoughtcrime

3002.95.text:
Now he had recognized himself as a dead man

3009.15.text:

3014.61.text:

3020.82.text:

3024.74.text:

3028.94.text:

3034.29.text:

3039.48.text:

3045.63.text:

quite useless to think of hiding it, but he

3050.98.text:

3055.16.text:

3060.33.text:

3065.28.text: to be shaken off if the book was moved.

3071.30.text: Winston was dreaming of his mother.

3074.12.text:
He must, he thought, have been ten or eleven

3078.54.text:
She was a tall, statuesque, rather silent
woman with slow movements and magnificent

3083.77.text:

3089.55.text:
clothes (Winston remembered especially the

3094.17.text:
wearing spectacles. The two of them must evidently

3101.86.text:
At this moment his mother was sitting in some

3105.90.text:

sister at all, except as a tiny, feeble baby,

3112.76.text:
always silent, with large, watchful eyes.
Both of them were looking up at him. They

3118.36.text:
were down in some subterranean place — the
bottom of a well, for instance, or a very

3122.42.text:
deep grave — but it was a place which, already
far below him, was itself moving downwards.

3129.40.text:
They were in the saloon of a sinking ship,
looking up at him through the darkening water.

3134.00.text:
There was still air in the saloon, they could
still see him and he them, but all the while

3137.89.text:
they were sinking down, down into the green
waters which in another moment must hide them

3142.55.text:
from sight for ever. He was out in the light
and air while they were being sucked down

3148.53.text:
to death, and they were down there because
he was up here. He knew it and they knew it,

3153.86.text:
and he could see the knowledge in their faces.
There was no reproach either in their faces

3158.31.text:
or in their hearts, only the knowledge that
they must die in order that he might remain

3162.76.text:

3168.29.text:
He could not remember what had happened, but
he knew in his dream that in some way the

3172.36.text:

sacrificed to his own. It was one of those

3177.36.text:

3182.31.text:

aware of facts and ideas which still seem

3187.39.text:

that now suddenly struck Winston was that

3192.51.text:

had been tragic and sorrowful in a way that

3197.11.text:
was no longer possible. Tragedy, he perceived,
belonged to the ancient time, to a time when

3202.94.text:
there was still privacy, love, and friendship,
and when the members of a family stood by

3206.82.text:
one another without needing to know the reason.
His mother's memory tore at his heart because

3212.40.text:
she had died loving him, when he was too young
and selfish to love her in return, and because

3217.87.text:
somehow, he did not remember how, she had
sacrificed herself to a conception of loyalty

3222.34.text:
that was private and unalterable. Such things,
he saw, could not happen today. Today there

3229.83.text:
were fear, hatred, and pain, but no dignity
of emotion, no deep or complex sorrows. All

3237.65.text:

his mother and his sister, looking up at him

3242.62.text:
through the green water, hundreds of fathoms

3249.33.text:
Suddenly he was standing on short springy

3253.78.text:

3259.39.text:

3263.21.text:

3269.56.text:

3275.54.text:

3279.27.text:

3285.99.text:

3291.12.text: swimming in the pools under the willow trees.

3294.74.text:

3299.29.text:

3305.22.text:

3312.10.text:

3315.70.text:

3321.70.text:

3325.54.text:

splendid movement of the arm. That too was

3332.25.text:
a gesture belonging to the ancient time. Winston
woke up with the word 'Shakespeare' on his

3339.82.text:

3354.98.text:

3369.94.text:

3374.66.text:

3379.64.text:

3440.11.text:

3453.56.text:

3458.09.text:

3462.80.text:

3480.24.text:

3484.72.text:

3488.50.text:

3494.11.text:

3498.61.text:

3515.26.text:

3519.95.text:

3529.68.text:

3549.98.text:

3554.90.text:

3576.56.text:

3584.97.text:

3588.23.text:
'We didn't ought to 'ave trusted 'em. I said

3592.68.text:

3595.84.text:

3600.74.text:
Since about that time, war had been literally

3608.12.text:
not always been the same war. For several

3612.20.text:

3616.42.text:

3621.11.text:

3625.46.text:

3630.58.text:

3637.91.text:

3652.51.text:

3656.22.text:

3662.02.text:

3668.62.text:
The enemy of the moment always represented

3673.55.text: or future agreement with him was impossible.

3676.88.text:

3681.94.text:

3685.88.text:

3696.79.text:

3704.92.text:

3710.52.text:

3716.16.text:

3721.86.text:

3727.07.text:

3733.19.text:

3739.21.text:
controls the past.' And yet the past, though

3747.70.text:

3754.53.text:

3768.87.text:

3774.29.text:

3781.13.text:

3786.50.text:

3792.11.text:

3803.61.text:

3808.82.text:

3813.97.text:

3822.62.text:

3828.16.text:
Even to understand the word 'doublethink'

3833.47.text:
The instructress had called them to attention

3844.85.text:

3853.43.text:

3857.97.text:

3863.40.text:

He tried to remember in what year he had first

3868.69.text:

must have been at some time in the sixties,

3873.87.text:

3878.73.text:

3884.18.text:

3888.52.text:

3893.45.text:

3898.91.text:

3905.29.text:

3909.41.text:

3915.42.text:

3920.43.text:

3930.90.text:

3935.95.text:

3941.61.text:
he had held in his hands unmistakable documentary

3949.17.text:

3959.67.text:
better, comrade. Now stand at ease, the whole

3964.11.text:

3969.01.text:
inscrutable. Never show dismay! Never show

3972.98.text:

3978.31.text:

3983.03.text:

3986.42.text:
