3995.51.text:
bent. You can all do it if you want to,' she
added as she straightened herself up. 'Anyone

4000.22.text:
under forty-five is perfectly capable of touching
his toes. We don't all have the privilege

4004.06.text:
of fighting in the front line, but at least
we can all keep fit. Remember our boys on

4008.05.text:
the Malabar front! And the sailors in the
Floating Fortresses! Just think what they

4011.39.text:
have to put up with. Now try again. That's
better, comrade, that's much better,' she

4015.94.text:
added encouragingly as Winston, with a violent
lunge, succeeded in touching his toes with

4020.38.text:
knees unbent, for the first time in several
years.

4026.91.text:
With the deep, unconscious sigh which not
even the nearness of the telescreen could

4030.73.text:
prevent him from uttering when his day's work
started, Winston pulled the speakwrite towards

4035.50.text:
him, blew the dust from its mouthpiece, and
put on his spectacles. Then he unrolled and

4040.61.text:
clipped together four small cylinders of paper
which had already flopped out of the pneumatic

4045.52.text: tube on the right-hand side of his desk.

4046.92.text:
In the walls of the cubicle there were three
orifices. To the right of the speakwrite,

4052.16.text:
a small pneumatic tube for written messages,
to the left, a larger one for newspapers;

4057.31.text:
and in the side wall, within easy reach of
Winston's arm, a large oblong slit protected

4062.21.text:
by a wire grating. This last was for the disposal
of waste paper. Similar slits existed in thousands

4069.61.text:
or tens of thousands throughout the building,
not only in every room but at short intervals

4073.67.text:
in every corridor. For some reason they were
nicknamed memory holes. When one knew that

4078.76.text:
any document was due for destruction, or even
when one saw a scrap of waste paper lying

4083.47.text:
about, it was an automatic action to lift
the flap of the nearest memory hole and drop

4087.47.text:
it in, whereupon it would be whirled away
on a current of warm air to the enormous furnaces

4092.25.text:
which were hidden somewhere in the recesses
of the building.

4096.34.text:
Winston examined the four slips of paper which
he had unrolled. Each contained a message

4100.42.text:
of only one or two lines, in the abbreviated
jargon — not actually Newspeak, but consisting

4105.64.text:
largely of Newspeak words — which was used
in the Ministry for internal purposes. They

4112.47.text:
times 17.3.84 bb speech malreported africa
rectify

4119.20.text:
times 19.12.83 forecasts 3 yp 4th quarter
83 misprints verify current issue

4134.40.text:
times 3.12.83 reporting bb dayorder doubleplusungood
refs unpersons rewrite fullwise upsub antefiling

4145.38.text:
With a faint feeling of satisfaction Winston
laid the fourth message aside. It was an intricate

4149.97.text:
and responsible job and had better be dealt
with last. The other three were routine matters,

4154.82.text:
though the second one would probably mean
some tedious wading through lists of figures.

4159.93.text:
Winston dialled 'back numbers' on the telescreen
and called for the appropriate issues of the

4164.30.text:
Times, which slid out of the pneumatic tube
after only a few minutes" delay. The messages

4169.65.text:
he had received referred to articles or news
items which for one reason or another it was

4173.40.text:
thought necessary to alter, or, as the official
phrase had it, to rectify. For example, it

4178.92.text:
appeared from the Times of the seventeenth
of March that Big Brother, in his speech of

4182.71.text:
the previous day, had predicted that the South
Indian front would remain quiet but that a

4187.02.text:
Eurasian offensive would shortly be launched
in North Africa. As it happened, the Eurasian

4191.65.text:
Higher Command had launched its offensive
in South India and left North Africa alone.

4196.24.text:
It was therefore necessary to rewrite a paragraph
of Big Brother's speech, in such a way as

4200.78.text:
to make him predict the thing that had actually
happened. Or again, the Times of the nineteenth

4205.93.text:
of December had published the official forecasts
of the output of various classes of consumption

4210.26.text:
goods in the fourth quarter of 1983, which
was also the sixth quarter of the Ninth Three-Year

4215.57.text:
Plan. Today's issue contained a statement
of the actual output, from which it appeared

4219.79.text:
that the forecasts were in every instance
grossly wrong. Winston's job was to rectify

4225.43.text:
the original figures by making them agree
with the later ones. As for the third message,

4230.38.text:
it referred to a very simple error which could
be set right in a couple of minutes. As short

4234.38.text:
a time ago as February, the Ministry of Plenty
had issued a promise (a 'categorical pledge'

4239.19.text:
were the official words) that there would
be no reduction of the chocolate ration during

4243.32.text:
1984. Actually, as Winston was aware, the
chocolate ration was to be reduced from thirty

4248.17.text:
grammes to twenty at the end of the present
week. All that was needed was to substitute

4252.30.text:
for the original promise a warning that it
would probably be necessary to reduce the

4256.17.text: ration at some time in April.

4258.31.text:
As soon as Winston had dealt with each of
the messages, he clipped his speakwritten

4262.43.text:
corrections to the appropriate copy of the
Times and pushed them into the pneumatic tube.

4267.05.text:
Then, with a movement which was as nearly
as possible unconscious, he crumpled up the

4271.41.text:
original message and any notes that he himself
had made, and dropped them into the memory

4275.77.text: hole to be devoured by the flames.

4279.05.text:
What happened in the unseen labyrinth to which
the pneumatic tubes led, he did not know in

4284.30.text:
detail, but he did know in general terms.
As soon as all the corrections which happened

4288.44.text:
to be necessary in any particular number of
the Times had been assembled and collated,

4292.92.text:
that number would be reprinted, the original
copy destroyed, and the corrected copy placed

4298.18.text:
on the files in its stead. This process of
continuous alteration was applied not only

4303.45.text:
to newspapers, but to books, periodicals,
pamphlets, posters, leaflets, films, sound-tracks,

4309.53.text:
cartoons, photographs — to every kind of
literature or documentation which might conceivably

4314.20.text:
hold any political or ideological significance.
Day by day and almost minute by minute the

4319.95.text:
past was brought up to date. In this way every
prediction made by the Party could be shown

4325.42.text:
by documentary evidence to have been correct,
nor was any item of news, or any expression

4330.57.text:
of opinion, which conflicted with the needs
of the moment, ever allowed to remain on record.

4335.73.text:
All history was a palimpsest, scraped clean
and reinscribed exactly as often as was necessary.

4342.67.text:
In no case would it have been possible, once
the deed was done, to prove that any falsification

4347.07.text:
had taken place. The largest section of the
Records Department, far larger than the one

4351.43.text:
on which Winston worked, consisted simply
of persons whose duty it was to track down

4355.84.text:
and collect all copies of books, newspapers,
and other documents which had been superseded

4361.06.text:
and were due for destruction. A number of
the Times which might, because of changes

4365.73.text:
in political alignment, or mistaken prophecies
uttered by Big Brother, have been rewritten

4370.27.text:
a dozen times still stood on the files bearing
its original date, and no other copy existed

4376.01.text:
to contradict it. Books, also, were recalled
and rewritten again and again, and were invariably

4381.96.text:
reissued without any admission that any alteration
had been made. Even the written instructions

4387.23.text:
which Winston received, and which he invariably
got rid of as soon as he had dealt with them,

4391.82.text:
never stated or implied that an act of forgery
was to be committed: always the reference

4396.55.text:
was to slips, errors, misprints, or misquotations
which it was necessary to put right in the

4404.12.text:
But actually, he thought as he re-adjusted
the Ministry of Plenty's figures, it was not

4407.67.text:
even forgery. It was merely the substitution
of one piece of nonsense for another. Most

4413.54.text:
of the material that you were dealing with
had no connexion with anything in the real

4417.08.text:
world, not even the kind of connexion that
is contained in a direct lie. Statistics were

4421.19.text:
just as much a fantasy in their original version
as in their rectified version. A great deal

4426.36.text:
of the time you were expected to make them
up out of your head. For example, the Ministry

4429.89.text:
of Plenty's forecast had estimated the output
of boots for the quarter at 145 million pairs.

4436.54.text:
The actual output was given as sixty-two millions.
Winston, however, in rewriting the forecast,

4442.11.text:
marked the figure down to fifty-seven millions,
so as to allow for the usual claim that the

4446.15.text:
quota had been overfulfilled. In any case,
sixty-two millions was no nearer the truth

4451.68.text:
than fifty-seven millions, or than 145 millions.
Very likely no boots had been produced at

4457.72.text:
all. Likelier still, nobody knew how many
had been produced, much less cared. All one

4462.82.text:
knew was that every quarter astronomical numbers
of boots were produced on paper, while perhaps

4467.98.text:
half the population of Oceania went barefoot.
And so it was with every class of recorded

4473.38.text:
fact, great or small. Everything faded away
into a shadow-world in which, finally, even

4480.65.text: the date of the year had become uncertain.

4484.97.text:
Winston glanced across the hall. In the corresponding
cubicle on the other side a small, precise-looking,

4490.92.text:
dark-chinned man named Tillotson was working
steadily away, with a folded newspaper on

4495.68.text:
his knee and his mouth very close to the mouthpiece
of the speakwrite. He had the air of trying

4500.70.text:
to keep what he was saying a secret between
himself and the telescreen. He looked up,

4505.53.text:
and his spectacles darted a hostile flash
in Winston's direction.

4509.94.text:
Winston hardly knew Tillotson, and had no
idea what work he was employed on. People

4514.17.text:
in the Records Department did not readily
talk about their jobs. In the long, windowless

4518.95.text:
hall, with its double row of cubicles and
its endless rustle of papers and hum of voices

4523.62.text:
murmuring into speakwrites, there were quite
a dozen people whom Winston did not even know

4528.05.text:
by name, though he daily saw them hurrying
to and fro in the corridors or gesticulating

4532.95.text:
in the Two Minutes Hate. He knew that in the
cubicle next to him the little woman with

4537.33.text:
sandy hair toiled day in day out, simply at
tracking down and deleting from the Press

4542.17.text:
the names of people who had been vaporized
and were therefore considered never to have

4546.15.text:
existed. There was a certain fitness in this,
since her own husband had been vaporized a

4550.34.text:
couple of years earlier. And a few cubicles
away a mild, ineffectual, dreamy creature

4556.15.text:
named Ampleforth, with very hairy ears and
a surprising talent for juggling with rhymes

4557.65.text:
and metres, was engaged in producing garbled
versions — definitive texts, they were called

4562.51.text:
— of poems which had become ideologically
offensive, but which for one reason or another

4567.09.text:
were to be retained in the anthologies. And
this hall, with its fifty workers or thereabouts,

4572.83.text:
was only one sub-section, a single cell, as
it were, in the huge complexity of the Records

4578.20.text:
Department. Beyond, above, below, were other
swarms of workers engaged in an unimaginable

4584.95.text:
multitude of jobs. There were the huge printing-shops
with their sub-editors, their typography experts,

4591.16.text:
and their elaborately equipped studios for
the faking of photographs. There was the tele-programmes

4596.26.text:
section with its engineers, its producers,
and its teams of actors specially chosen for

4600.97.text:
their skill in imitating voices. There were
the armies of reference clerks whose job was

4605.73.text:
simply to draw up lists of books and periodicals
which were due for recall. There were the

4610.36.text:
vast repositories where the corrected documents
were stored, and the hidden furnaces where

4614.77.text:
the original copies were destroyed. And somewhere
or other, quite anonymous, there were the

4619.84.text:
directing brains who co-ordinated the whole
effort and laid down the lines of policy which

4625.44.text:
made it necessary that this fragment of the
past should be preserved, that one falsified,

4630.21.text: and the other rubbed out of existence.

4633.62.text:
And the Records Department, after all, was
itself only a single branch of the Ministry

4637.16.text:
of Truth, whose primary job was not to reconstruct
the past but to supply the citizens of Oceania

4643.14.text:
with newspapers, films, textbooks, telescreen
programmes, plays, novels — with every conceivable

4648.57.text:
kind of information, instruction, or entertainment,
from a statue to a slogan, from a lyric poem

4654.26.text:
to a biological treatise, and from a child's
spelling-book to a Newspeak dictionary. And

4659.73.text:
the Ministry had not only to supply the multifarious
needs of the party, but also to repeat the

4664.64.text:
whole operation at a lower level for the benefit
of the proletariat. There was a whole chain

4669.67.text:
of separate departments dealing with proletarian
literature, music, drama, and entertainment

4675.71.text:
generally. Here were produced rubbishy newspapers
containing almost nothing except sport, crime

4680.57.text:
and astrology, sensational five-cent novelettes,
films oozing with sex, and sentimental songs

4687.03.text:
which were composed entirely by mechanical
means on a special kind of kaleidoscope known

4691.51.text:
as a versificator. There was even a whole
sub-section — Pornosec, it was called in

4696.45.text:
Newspeak — engaged in producing the lowest
kind of pornography, which was sent out in

4701.13.text:
sealed packets and which no Party member,
other than those who worked on it, was permitted

4707.44.text:
Three messages had slid out of the pneumatic
tube while Winston was working, but they were

4711.46.text:
simple matters, and he had disposed of them
before the Two Minutes Hate interrupted him.

4716.39.text:
When the Hate was over he returned to his
cubicle, took the Newspeak dictionary from

4720.51.text:
the shelf, pushed the speakwrite to one side,
cleaned his spectacles, and settled down to

4725.45.text: his main job of the morning.

4728.78.text:
Winston's greatest pleasure in life was in
his work. Most of it was a tedious routine,

4733.99.text:
but included in it there were also jobs so
difficult and intricate that you could lose

4738.20.text:
yourself in them as in the depths of a mathematical
problem — delicate pieces of forgery in

4743.80.text:
which you had nothing to guide you except
your knowledge of the principles of Ingsoc

4747.49.text:
and your estimate of what the Party wanted
you to say. Winston was good at this kind

4752.07.text:
of thing. On occasion he had even been entrusted
with the rectification of the Times leading

4757.46.text:
articles, which were written entirely in Newspeak.
He unrolled the message that he had set aside

4764.95.text:
times 3.12.83 reporting bb dayorder doubleplusungood
refs unpersons rewrite fullwise upsub antefiling

4775.17.text:
In Oldspeak (or standard English) this might
be rendered:

4778.89.text:
The reporting of Big Brother's Order for the
Day in the Times of December 3rd 1983 is extremely

4784.65.text:
unsatisfactory and makes references to non-existent
persons. Rewrite it in full and submit your

4790.89.text: draft to higher authority before filing.

4794.97.text:
Winston read through the offending article.
Big Brother's Order for the Day, it seemed,

4799.39.text:
had been chiefly devoted to praising the work
of an organization known as FFCC, which supplied

4804.73.text:
cigarettes and other comforts to the sailors
in the Floating Fortresses. A certain Comrade

4809.67.text:
Withers, a prominent member of the Inner Party,
had been singled out for special mention and

4813.86.text:
awarded a decoration, the Order of Conspicuous
Merit, Second Class.

4818.97.text:
Three months later FFCC had suddenly been
dissolved with no reasons given. One could

4823.57.text:
assume that Withers and his associates were
now in disgrace, but there had been no report

4827.74.text:
of the matter in the Press or on the telescreen.
That was to be expected, since it was unusual

4832.43.text:
for political offenders to be put on trial
or even publicly denounced. The great purges

4837.30.text:
involving thousands of people, with public
trials of traitors and thought-criminals who

4840.86.text:
made abject confession of their crimes and
were afterwards executed, were special show-pieces

4846.84.text:
not occurring oftener than once in a couple
of years. More commonly, people who had incurred

4852.08.text:
the displeasure of the Party simply disappeared
and were never heard of again. One never had

4856.82.text:
the smallest clue as to what had happened
to them. In some cases they might not even

4860.63.text:
be dead. Perhaps thirty people personally
known to Winston, not counting his parents,

4866.19.text: had disappeared at one time or another.

4869.34.text:
Winston stroked his nose gently with a paper-clip.
In the cubicle across the way Comrade Tillotson

4874.39.text:
was still crouching secretively over his speakwrite.
He raised his head for a moment: again the

4879.49.text:
hostile spectacle-flash. Winston wondered
whether Comrade Tillotson was engaged on the

4885.44.text:
same job as himself. It was perfectly possible.
So tricky a piece of work would never be entrusted

4891.02.text:
to a single person: on the other hand, to
turn it over to a committee would be to admit

4895.07.text:
openly that an act of fabrication was taking
place. Very likely as many as a dozen people

4900.30.text:
were now working away on rival versions of
what Big Brother had actually said. And presently

4905.42.text:
some master brain in the Inner Party would
select this version or that, would re-edit

4909.53.text:
it and set in motion the complex processes
of cross-referencing that would be required,

4914.79.text:
and then the chosen lie would pass into the
permanent records and become truth.

4920.76.text:
Winston did not know why Withers had been
disgraced. Perhaps it was for corruption or

4925.86.text:
incompetence. Perhaps Big Brother was merely
getting rid of a too-popular subordinate.

4929.87.text:
Perhaps Withers or someone close to him had
been suspected of heretical tendencies. Or

4934.19.text:
perhaps — what was likeliest of all — the
thing had simply happened because purges and

4938.76.text:
vaporizations were a necessary part of the
mechanics of government. The only real clue

4944.07.text:
lay in the words 'refs unpersons', which indicated
that Withers was already dead. You could not

4950.19.text:
invariably assume this to be the case when
people were arrested. Sometimes they were

4954.49.text:
released and allowed to remain at liberty
for as much as a year or two years before

4958.10.text:
being executed. Very occasionally some person
whom you had believed dead long since would

4963.41.text:
make a ghostly reappearance at some public
trial where he would implicate hundreds of

4967.70.text:
others by his testimony before vanishing,
this time for ever. Withers, however, was

4973.24.text:
already an unperson. He did not exist: he
had never existed. Winston decided that it

4979.68.text:
would not be enough simply to reverse the
tendency of Big Brother's speech. It was better

4984.14.text:
to make it deal with something totally unconnected
with its original subject.

4989.48.text:
He might turn the speech into the usual denunciation
of traitors and thought-criminals, but that

4994.49.text:
was a little too obvious, while to invent
a victory at the front, or some triumph of

4998.91.text:
over-production in the Ninth Three-Year Plan,
might complicate the records too much. What

5004.39.text:
was needed was a piece of pure fantasy. Suddenly
there sprang into his mind, ready made as

5010.33.text:
it were, the image of a certain Comrade Ogilvy,
who had recently died in battle, in heroic

5015.72.text:
circumstances. There were occasions when Big
Brother devoted his Order for the Day to commemorating

5021.00.text:
some humble, rank-and-file Party member whose
life and death he held up as an example worthy

5026.17.text:
to be followed. Today he should commemorate
Comrade Ogilvy. It was true that there was

5031.83.text:
no such person as Comrade Ogilvy, but a few
lines of print and a couple of faked photographs

5036.24.text: would soon bring him into existence.

5039.66.text:
Winston thought for a moment, then pulled
the speakwrite towards him and began dictating

5043.69.text:
in Big Brother's familiar style: a style at
once military and pedantic, and, because of

5048.89.text:
a trick of asking questions and then promptly
answering them ('What lessons do we learn

5053.37.text:
from this fact, comrades? The lesson — which
is also one of the fundamental principles

5058.14.text:
of Ingsoc — that,' etc., etc.), easy to
imitate.

5063.05.text:
At the age of three Comrade Ogilvy had refused
all toys except a drum, a sub-machine gun,

5068.47.text:
and a model helicopter. At six — a year
early, by a special relaxation of the rules

5073.44.text:
— he had joined the Spies, at nine he had
been a troop leader. At eleven he had denounced

5078.85.text:
his uncle to the Thought Police after overhearing
a conversation which appeared to him to have

5082.80.text:
criminal tendencies. At seventeen he had been
a district organizer of the Junior Anti-Sex

5088.35.text:
League. At nine teen he had designed a hand-grenade
which had been adopted by the Ministry of

5093.12.text:
Peace and which, at its first trial, had killed
thirty-one Eurasian prisoners in one burst.

5098.60.text:
At twenty-three he had perished in action.
Pursued by enemy jet planes while flying over

5104.64.text:
the Indian Ocean with important despatches,
he had weighted his body with his machine

5108.66.text:
gun and leapt out of the helicopter into deep
water, despatches and all — an end, said

5114.01.text:
Big Brother, which it was impossible to contemplate
without feelings of envy. Big Brother added

5119.08.text:
a few remarks on the purity and single-mindedness
of Comrade Ogilvy's life. He was a total abstainer

5124.86.text:
and a nonsmoker, had no recreations except
a daily hour in the gymnasium, and had taken

5129.74.text:
a vow of celibacy, believing marriage and
the care of a family to be incompatible with

5134.34.text:
a twenty-four-hour-a-day devotion to duty.
He had no subjects of conversation except

5139.69.text:
the principles of Ingsoc, and no aim in life
except the defeat of the Eurasian enemy and

5145.31.text:
the hunting-down of spies, saboteurs, thoughtcriminals,
and traitors generally.

5150.80.text:
Winston debated with himself whether to award
Comrade Ogilvy the Order of Conspicuous Merit:

5155.96.text:
in the end he decided against it because of
the unnecessary cross-referencing that it

5161.61.text:
Once again he glanced at his rival in the
opposite cubicle. Something seemed to tell

5165.82.text:
him with certainty that Tillotson was busy
on the same job as himself. There was no way

5169.99.text:
of knowing whose job would finally be adopted,
but he felt a profound conviction that it

5174.37.text:
would be his own. Comrade Ogilvy, unimagined
an hour ago, was now a fact. It struck him

5180.07.text:
as curious that you could create dead men
but not living ones. Comrade Ogilvy, who had

5185.37.text:
never existed in the present, now existed
in the past, and when once the act of forgery

5191.01.text:
was forgotten, he would exist just as authentically,
and upon the same evidence, as Charlemagne

5201.92.text:
In the low-ceilinged canteen, deep underground,
the lunch queue jerked slowly forward. The

5208.15.text:
room was already very full and deafeningly
noisy. From the grille at the counter the

5212.80.text:
steam of stew came pouring forth, with a sour
metallic smell which did not quite overcome

5218.22.text:
the fumes of Victory Gin. On the far side
of the room there was a small bar, a mere

5223.30.text:
hole in the wall, where gin could be bought
at ten cents the large nip.

5227.90.text:
'Just the man I was looking for,' said a voice
at Winston's back.

5231.24.text:
He turned round. It was his friend Syme, who
worked in the Research Department. Perhaps

5237.50.text:
'friend' was not exactly the right word. You
did not have friends nowadays, you had comrades:

5242.75.text:
but there were some comrades whose society
was pleasanter than that of others. Syme was

5249.06.text:
a philologist, a specialist in Newspeak. Indeed,
he was one of the enormous team of experts

5253.89.text:
now engaged in compiling the Eleventh Edition
of the Newspeak Dictionary. He was a tiny

5259.56.text:
creature, smaller than Winston, with dark
hair and large, protuberant eyes, at once

5264.09.text:
mournful and derisive, which seemed to search
your face closely while he was speaking to

5270.12.text:
'I wanted to ask you whether you'd got any
razor blades,' he said.

5273.95.text:
'Not one!' said Winston with a sort of guilty
haste. 'I've tried all over the place. They

5280.89.text:
Everyone kept asking you for razor blades.
Actually he had two unused ones which he was

5286.92.text:
hoarding up. There had been a famine of them
for months past. At any given moment there

5292.20.text:
was some necessary article which the Party
shops were unable to supply. Sometimes it

5296.95.text:
was buttons, sometimes it was darning wool,
sometimes it was shoelaces; at present it

5301.43.text:
was razor blades. You could only get hold
of them, if at all, by scrounging more or

5308.27.text:
'I've been using the same blade for six weeks,'
he added untruthfully.

5313.06.text:
The queue gave another jerk forward. As they
halted he turned and faced Syme again. Each

5318.38.text:
of them took a greasy metal tray from a pile
at the end of the counter.

5323.08.text:
'Did you go and see the prisoners hanged yesterday?'
said Syme.

5325.68.text:
'I was working,' said Winston indifferently.
'I shall see it on the flicks, I suppose.'

5334.75.text:
His mocking eyes roved over Winston's face.
'I know you,' the eyes seemed to say, 'I see

5340.78.text:
through you. I know very well why you didn't
go to see those prisoners hanged.' In an intellectual

5347.04.text:
way, Syme was venomously orthodox. He would
talk with a disagreeable gloating satisfaction

5352.49.text:
of helicopter raids on enemy villages, and
trials and confessions of thought-criminals,

5357.60.text:
the executions in the cellars of the Ministry
of Love. Talking to him was largely a matter

5363.56.text:
of getting him away from such subjects and
entangling him, if possible, in the technicalities

5368.15.text:
of Newspeak, on which he was authoritative
and interesting. Winston turned his head a

5373.52.text:
little aside to avoid the scrutiny of the
large dark eyes.

5377.46.text:
'It was a good hanging,' said Syme reminiscently.
'I think it spoils it when they tie their

5383.15.text:
feet together. I like to see them kicking.
And above all, at the end, the tongue sticking

5387.55.text:
right out, and blue — a quite bright blue.
That's the detail that appeals to me.'

5391.56.text:
'Nex', please!' yelled the white-aproned prole
with the ladle.

5397.08.text:
Winston and Syme pushed their trays beneath
the grille. On to each was dumped swiftly

5401.93.text:
the regulation lunch — a metal pannikin
of pinkish-grey stew, a hunk of bread, a cube

5406.87.text:
of cheese, a mug of milkless Victory Coffee,
and one saccharine tablet.

5411.03.text:
'There's a table over there, under that telescreen,'
said Syme. 'Let's pick up a gin on the way.'

5417.30.text:
The gin was served out to them in handleless
china mugs. They threaded their way across

5421.86.text:
the crowded room and unpacked their trays
on to the metal-topped table, on one corner

5426.35.text:
of which someone had left a pool of stew,
a filthy liquid mess that had the appearance

5431.02.text:
of vomit. Winston took up his mug of gin,
paused for an instant to collect his nerve,

5436.74.text:
and gulped the oily-tasting stuff down. When
he had winked the tears out of his eyes he

5441.83.text:
suddenly discovered that he was hungry. He
began swallowing spoonfuls of the stew, which,

5447.24.text:
in among its general sloppiness, had cubes
of spongy pinkish stuff which was probably

5451.88.text:
a preparation of meat. Neither of them spoke
again till they had emptied their pannikins.

5457.55.text:
From the table at Winston's left, a little
behind his back, someone was talking rapidly

5461.46.text:
and continuously, a harsh gabble almost like
the quacking of a duck, which pierced the

5467.94.text:
'How is the Dictionary getting on?' said Winston,
raising his voice to overcome the noise.

5474.35.text:
'Slowly,' said Syme. 'I'm on the adjectives.
It's fascinating.'

5478.50.text:
He had brightened up immediately at the mention
of Newspeak. He pushed his pannikin aside,

5483.33.text:
took up his hunk of bread in one delicate
hand and his cheese in the other, and leaned

5487.53.text:
across the table so as to be able to speak
without shouting.

5491.01.text:
'The Eleventh Edition is the definitive edition,'
he said. 'We're getting the language into

5496.39.text:
its final shape — the shape it's going to
have when nobody speaks anything else. When

5500.93.text:
we've finished with it, people like you will
have to learn it all over again. You think,

5505.23.text:
I dare say, that our chief job is inventing
new words. But not a bit of it! We're destroying

5509.62.text:
words — scores of them, hundreds of them,
every day. We're cutting the language down

5514.39.text:
to the bone. The Eleventh Edition won't contain
a single word that will become obsolete before

5521.32.text:
He bit hungrily into his bread and swallowed
a couple of mouthfuls, then continued speaking,

5526.06.text:
with a sort of pedant's passion. His thin
dark face had become animated, his eyes had

5530.99.text:
lost their mocking expression and grown almost
dreamy.

5534.74.text:
'It's a beautiful thing, the destruction of
words. Of course the great wastage is in the

5539.93.text:
verbs and adjectives, but there are hundreds
of nouns that can be got rid of as well. It

5543.96.text:
isn't only the synonyms; there are also the
antonyms. After all, what justification is

5549.58.text:
there for a word which is simply the opposite
of some other word? A word contains its opposite

5554.55.text:
in itself. Take "good", for instance. If you
have a word like "good", what need is there

5559.99.text:
for a word like "bad"? "Ungood" will do just
as well — better, because it's an exact

5565.76.text:
opposite, which the other is not. Or again,
if you want a stronger version of "good",

5570.74.text:
what sense is there in having a whole string
of vague useless words like "excellent" and

5575.52.text:
"splendid" and all the rest of them? "Plusgood"
covers the meaning, or "doubleplusgood" if

5580.01.text:
you want something stronger still. Of course
we use those forms already. but in the final

5584.65.text:
version of Newspeak there'll be nothing else.
In the end the whole notion of goodness and

5589.28.text:
badness will be covered by only six words
— in reality, only one word. don't you see

5594.82.text:
the beauty of that, Winston? It was B. B.'s
idea originally, of course,' he added as an

5601.38.text:
A sort of vapid eagerness flitted across Winston's
face at the mention of Big Brother. Nevertheless

5607.07.text:
Syme immediately detected a certain lack of
enthusiasm.

5611.40.text:
'You haven't a real appreciation of Newspeak,
Winston,' he said almost sadly. 'Even when

5616.88.text:
you write it you're still thinking in Oldspeak.
I've read some of those pieces that you write

5621.03.text:
in the Times occasionally. They're good enough,
but they're translations. In your heart you'd

5625.80.text:
prefer to stick to Oldspeak, with all its
vagueness and its useless shades of meaning.

5630.69.text:
You don't grasp the beauty of the destruction
of words. Do you know that Newspeak is the

5635.74.text:
only language in the world whose vocabulary
gets smaller every year?'

5640.83.text:
Winston did know that, of course. He smiled,
sympathetically he hoped, not trusting himself

5645.42.text:
to speak. Syme bit off another fragment of
the dark-coloured bread, chewed it briefly,

5651.28.text:
'Don't you see that the whole aim of Newspeak
is to narrow the range of thought? In the

5656.36.text:
end we shall make thoughtcrime literally impossible,
because there will be no words in which to

5661.29.text:
express it. Every concept that can ever be
needed, will be expressed by exactly one word,

5666.83.text:
with its meaning rigidly defined and all its
subsidiary meanings rubbed out and forgotten.

5671.86.text:
Already, in the Eleventh Edition, we're not
far from that point. But the process will

5676.07.text:
still be continuing long after you and I are
dead. Every year fewer and fewer words, and

5681.63.text:
the range of consciousness always a little
smaller. Even now, of course, there's no reason

5686.10.text:
or excuse for committing thoughtcrime. It's
merely a question of self-discipline, reality-control.

5691.97.text:
But in the end there won't be any need even
for that. The Revolution will be complete

5696.45.text:
when the language is perfect. Newspeak is
Ingsoc and Ingsoc is Newspeak,' he added with

5702.76.text:
a sort of mystical satisfaction. 'Has it ever
occurred to you, Winston, that by the year

5708.71.text:
2050, at the very latest, not a single human
being will be alive who could understand such

5714.22.text: a conversation as we are having now?'

5717.43.text:
'Except—' began Winston doubtfully, and
he stopped.

5721.54.text:
It had been on the tip of his tongue to say
'Except the proles,' but he checked himself,

5726.56.text:
not feeling fully certain that this remark
was not in some way unorthodox. Syme, however,

5731.57.text: had divined what he was about to say.

5734.37.text:
'The proles are not human beings,' he said
carelessly. 'By 2050 — earlier, probably

5739.91.text:
— all real knowledge of Oldspeak will have
disappeared. The whole literature of the past

5744.51.text:
will have been destroyed. Chaucer, Shakespeare,
Milton, Byron — they'll exist only in Newspeak

5749.71.text:
versions, not merely changed into something
different, but actually changed into something

5754.66.text:
contradictory of what they used to be. Even
the literature of the Party will change. Even

5759.40.text:
the slogans will change. How could you have
a slogan like "freedom is slavery" when the

5763.76.text:
concept of freedom has been abolished? The
whole climate of thought will be different.

5768.53.text:
In fact there will be no thought, as we understand
it now. Orthodoxy means not thinking — not

5774.18.text: needing to think. Orthodoxy is unconsciousness.'

5779.16.text:
One of these days, thought Winston with sudden
deep conviction, Syme will be vaporized. He

5785.34.text:
is too intelligent. He sees too clearly and
speaks too plainly. The Party does not like

5790.50.text:
such people. One day he will disappear. It
is written in his face.

5796.87.text:
Winston had finished his bread and cheese.
He turned a little sideways in his chair to

5800.85.text:
drink his mug of coffee. At the table on his
left the man with the strident voice was still

5805.69.text:
talking remorselessly away. A young woman
who was perhaps his secretary, and who was

5811.00.text:
sitting with her back to Winston, was listening
to him and seemed to be eagerly agreeing with

5814.74.text:
everything that he said. From time to time
Winston caught some such remark as 'I think

5820.04.text:
you're so right, I do so agree with you',
uttered in a youthful and rather silly feminine

5824.89.text:
voice. But the other voice never stopped for
an instant, even when the girl was speaking.

5830.90.text:
Winston knew the man by sight, though he knew
no more about him than that he held some important

5835.66.text:
post in the Fiction Department. He was a man
of about thirty, with a muscular throat and

5840.44.text:
a large, mobile mouth. His head was thrown
back a little, and because of the angle at

5846.28.text:
which he was sitting, his spectacles caught
the light and presented to Winston two blank

5850.12.text:
discs instead of eyes. What was slightly horrible,
was that from the stream of sound that poured

5856.58.text:
out of his mouth it was almost impossible
to distinguish a single word. Just once Winston

5862.14.text:
caught a phrase — 'complete and final elimination
of Goldsteinism' — jerked out very rapidly

5867.35.text:
and, as it seemed, all in one piece, like
a line of type cast solid. For the rest it

5872.96.text:
was just a noise, a quack-quack-quacking.
And yet, though you could not actually hear

5877.47.text:
what the man was saying, you could not be
in any doubt about its general nature. He

5881.84.text:
might be denouncing Goldstein and demanding
sterner measures against thought-criminals

5885.85.text:
and saboteurs, he might be fulminating against
the atrocities of the Eurasian army, he might

5890.50.text:
be praising Big Brother or the heroes on the
Malabar front — it made no difference. Whatever

5896.02.text:
it was, you could be certain that every word
of it was pure orthodoxy, pure Ingsoc. As

5901.42.text:
he watched the eyeless face with the jaw moving
rapidly up and down, Winston had a curious

5906.20.text:
feeling that this was not a real human being
but some kind of dummy. It was not the man's

5911.06.text:
brain that was speaking, it was his larynx.
The stuff that was coming out of him consisted

5915.52.text:
of words, but it was not speech in the true
sense: it was a noise uttered in unconsciousness,

5920.91.text: like the quacking of a duck.

5924.01.text:
Syme had fallen silent for a moment, and with
the handle of his spoon was tracing patterns

5928.12.text:
in the puddle of stew. The voice from the
other table quacked rapidly on, easily audible

5933.51.text: in spite of the surrounding din.

5936.05.text:
'There is a word in Newspeak,' said Syme,
'I don't know whether you know it: duckspeak,

5942.34.text:
to quack like a duck. It is one of those interesting
words that have two contradictory meanings.

5947.11.text:
Applied to an opponent, it is abuse, applied
to someone you agree with, it is praise.'

5952.82.text:
Unquestionably Syme will be vaporized, Winston
thought again. He thought it with a kind of

5958.95.text:
sadness, although well knowing that Syme despised
him and slightly disliked him, and was fully

5963.79.text:
capable of denouncing him as a thought-criminal
if he saw any reason for doing so. There was

5968.88.text:
something subtly wrong with Syme. There was
something that he lacked: discretion, aloofness,

5974.98.text:
a sort of saving stupidity. You could not
say that he was unorthodox. He believed in

5980.51.text:
the principles of Ingsoc, he venerated Big
Brother, he rejoiced over victories, he hated

5985.29.text:
heretics, not merely with sincerity but with
a sort of restless zeal, an up-to-dateness

5990.35.text:
of information, which the ordinary Party member
did not approach. Yet a faint air of disreputability

5996.90.text:
always clung to him. He said things that would
have been better unsaid, he had read too many

6002.69.text:
books, he frequented the Chestnut Tree Café,
haunt of painters and musicians. There was

6008.98.text:
no law, not even an unwritten law, against
frequenting the Chestnut Tree Café, yet the

6013.59.text:
place was somehow ill-omened. The old, discredited
leaders of the Party had been used to gather

6020.04.text:
there before they were finally purged. Goldstein
himself, it was said, had sometimes been seen

6025.17.text:
there, years and decades ago. Syme's fate
was not difficult to foresee. And yet it was

6031.69.text:
a fact that if Syme grasped, even for three
seconds, the nature of his, Winston's, secret

6037.20.text:
opinions, he would betray him instantly to
the Thought police. So would anybody else,

6042.16.text:
for that matter: but Syme more than most.
Zeal was not enough. Orthodoxy was unconsciousness.

6050.14.text: Syme looked up. 'Here comes Parsons,' he said.

6053.74.text:
Something in the tone of his voice seemed
to add, 'that bloody fool'. Parsons, Winston's

6059.25.text:
fellow-tenant at Victory Mansions, was in
fact threading his way across the room — a

6063.59.text:
tubby, middle-sized man with fair hair and
a froglike face. At thirty-five he was already

6069.62.text:
putting on rolls of fat at neck and waistline,
but his movements were brisk and boyish. His

6075.95.text:
whole appearance was that of a little boy
grown large, so much so that although he was

6080.71.text:
wearing the regulation overalls, it was almost
impossible not to think of him as being dressed

6084.83.text:
in the blue shorts, grey shirt, and red neckerchief
of the Spies. In visualizing him one saw always

6091.51.text:
a picture of dimpled knees and sleeves rolled
back from pudgy forearms. Parsons did, indeed,

6098.60.text:
invariably revert to shorts when a community
hike or any other physical activity gave him

6103.19.text:
an excuse for doing so. He greeted them both
with a cheery 'Hullo, hullo!' and sat down

6108.81.text:
at the table, giving off an intense smell
of sweat. Beads of moisture stood out all

6114.19.text:
over his pink face. His powers of sweating
were extraordinary. At the Community Centre

6119.50.text:
you could always tell when he had been playing
table-tennis by the dampness of the bat handle.

6125.34.text:
Syme had produced a strip of paper on which
there was a long column of words, and was

6129.27.text:
studying it with an ink-pencil between his
fingers.

6131.88.text:
'Look at him working away in the lunch hour,'
said Parsons, nudging Winston. 'Keenness,

6138.82.text:
eh? What's that you've got there, old boy?
Something a bit too brainy for me, I expect.

6142.77.text:
Smith, old boy, I'll tell you why I'm chasing
you. It's that sub you forgot to give me.'

6147.47.text:
'Which sub is that?' said Winston, automatically
feeling for money. About a quarter of one's

6152.20.text:
salary had to be earmarked for voluntary subscriptions,
which were so numerous that it was difficult

6157.88.text:
'For Hate Week. You know — the house-by-house
fund. I'm treasurer for our block. We're making

6163.16.text:
an all-out effort — going to put on a tremendous
show. I tell you, it won't be my fault if

6167.70.text:
old Victory Mansions doesn't have the biggest
outfit of flags in the whole street. Two dollars

6173.92.text:
Winston found and handed over two creased
and filthy notes, which Parsons entered in

6178.29.text:
a small notebook, in the neat handwriting
of the illiterate.

6180.74.text:
'By the way, old boy,' he said. 'I hear that
little beggar of mine let fly at you with

6185.80.text:
his catapult yesterday. I gave him a good
dressing-down for it. In fact I told him I'd

6190.00.text: take the catapult away if he does it again.'

6191.91.text:
'I think he was a little upset at not going
to the execution,' said Winston.

6197.05.text:
'Ah, well — what I mean to say, shows the
right spirit, doesn't it? Mischievous little

6202.31.text:
beggars they are, both of them, but talk about
keenness! All they think about is the Spies,

6206.69.text:
and the war, of course. D'you know what that
little girl of mine did last Saturday, when

6211.27.text:
her troop was on a hike out Berkhamsted way?
She got two other girls to go with her, slipped

6217.08.text:
off from the hike, and spent the whole afternoon
following a strange man. They kept on his

6221.60.text:
tail for two hours, right through the woods,
and then, when they got into Amersham, handed

6226.69.text:
'What did they do that for?' said Winston,
somewhat taken aback. Parsons went on triumphantly:

6232.56.text:
'My kid made sure he was some kind of enemy
agent — might have been dropped by parachute,

6237.64.text:
for instance. But here's the point, old boy.
What do you think put her on to him in the

6241.95.text:
first place? She spotted he was wearing a
funny kind of shoes — said she'd never seen

6246.54.text:
anyone wearing shoes like that before. So
the chances were he was a foreigner. Pretty

6250.66.text: smart for a nipper of seven, eh?'

6253.52.text: 'What happened to the man?' said Winston.

6255.81.text:
'Ah, that I couldn't say, of course. But I
wouldn't be altogether surprised if—' Parsons

6261.58.text:
made the motion of aiming a rifle, and clicked
his tongue for the explosion.

6265.79.text:
'Good,' said Syme abstractedly, without looking
up from his strip of paper.

6270.19.text:
'Of course we can't afford to take chances,'
agreed Winston dutifully.

6274.54.text:
'What I mean to say, there is a war on,' said
Parsons.

6279.80.text:
As though in confirmation of this, a trumpet
call floated from the telescreen just above

6283.38.text:
their heads. However, it was not the proclamation
of a military victory this time, but merely

6288.62.text: an announcement from the Ministry of Plenty.

6291.30.text:
'Comrades!' cried an eager youthful voice.
'Attention, comrades! We have glorious news

6296.17.text:
for you. We have won the battle for production!
Returns now completed of the output of all

6301.31.text:
classes of consumption goods show that the
standard of living has risen by no less than

6305.57.text:
20 per cent over the past year. All over Oceania
this morning there were irrepressible spontaneous

6311.51.text:
demonstrations when workers marched out of
factories and offices and paraded through

6315.63.text:
the streets with banners voicing their gratitude
to Big Brother for the new, happy life which

6320.49.text:
his wise leadership has bestowed upon us.
Here are some of the completed figures. Foodstuffs—'

6326.05.text:
The phrase 'our new, happy life' recurred
several times. It had been a favourite of

6331.40.text:
late with the Ministry of Plenty. Parsons,
his attention caught by the trumpet call,

6336.07.text:
sat listening with a sort of gaping solemnity,
a sort of edified boredom. He could not follow

6342.24.text:
the figures, but he was aware that they were
in some way a cause for satisfaction. He had

6346.64.text:
lugged out a huge and filthy pipe which was
already half full of charred tobacco. With

6351.99.text:
the tobacco ration at 100 grammes a week it
was seldom possible to fill a pipe to the

6356.12.text:
top. Winston was smoking a Victory Cigarette
which he held carefully horizontal. The new

6361.41.text:
ration did not start till tomorrow and he
had only four cigarettes left. For the moment

6366.00.text:
he had shut his ears to the remoter noises
and was listening to the stuff that streamed

6370.34.text:
out of the telescreen. It appeared that there
had even been demonstrations to thank Big

6375.40.text:
Brother for raising the chocolate ration to
twenty grammes a week. And only yesterday,

6380.04.text:
he reflected, it had been announced that the
ration was to be reduced to twenty grammes

6384.08.text:
a week. Was it possible that they could swallow
that, after only twenty-four hours? Yes, they

6390.78.text:
swallowed it. Parsons swallowed it easily,
with the stupidity of an animal. The eyeless

6396.76.text:
creature at the other table swallowed it fanatically,
passionately, with a furious desire to track

6401.98.text:
down, denounce, and vaporize anyone who should
suggest that last week the ration had been

6406.89.text:
thirty grammes. Syme, too — in some more
complex way, involving doublethink, Syme swallowed

6414.87.text:
it. Was he, then, alone in the possession
of a memory?

6420.03.text:
The fabulous statistics continued to pour
out of the telescreen. As compared with last

6424.65.text:
year there was more food, more clothes, more
houses, more furniture, more cooking-pots,

6429.73.text:
more fuel, more ships, more helicopters, more
books, more babies — more of everything

6434.71.text:
except disease, crime, and insanity. Year
by year and minute by minute, everybody and

6440.95.text:
everything was whizzing rapidly upwards. As
Syme had done earlier Winston had taken up

6447.30.text:
his spoon and was dabbling in the pale-coloured
gravy that dribbled across the table, drawing

6452.14.text:
a long streak of it out into a pattern. He
meditated resentfully on the physical texture

6457.65.text:
of life. Had it always been like this? Had
food always tasted like this? He looked round

6464.35.text:
the canteen. A low-ceilinged, crowded room,
its walls grimy from the contact of innumerable

6470.76.text:
bodies; battered metal tables and chairs,
placed so close together that you sat with

6475.15.text:
elbows touching; bent spoons, dented trays,
coarse white mugs; all surfaces greasy, grime

6481.91.text:
in every crack; and a sourish, composite smell
of bad gin and bad coffee and metallic stew

6487.55.text:
and dirty clothes. Always in your stomach
and in your skin there was a sort of protest,

6493.12.text:
a feeling that you had been cheated of something
that you had a right to. It was true that

6498.23.text:
he had no memories of anything greatly different.
In any time that he could accurately remember,

6504.02.text:
there had never been quite enough to eat,
one had never had socks or underclothes that

6507.86.text:
were not full of holes, furniture had always
been battered and rickety, rooms underheated,

6512.75.text:
tube trains crowded, houses falling to pieces,
bread dark-coloured, tea a rarity, coffee

6517.88.text:
filthy-tasting, cigarettes insufficient — nothing
cheap and plentiful except synthetic gin.

6525.23.text:
And though, of course, it grew worse as one's
body aged, was it not a sign that this was

6530.32.text:
not the natural order of things, if one's
heart sickened at the discomfort and dirt

6535.35.text:
and scarcity, the interminable winters, the
stickiness of one's socks, the lifts that

6540.10.text:
never worked, the cold water, the gritty soap,
the cigarettes that came to pieces, the food

6545.16.text:
with its strange evil tastes? Why should one
feel it to be intolerable unless one had some

6551.76.text:

6555.41.text:

6561.40.text:

6566.90.text:

6571.66.text:

6579.45.text:

6584.18.text:
up by the Party as an ideal-tall muscular
youths and deep-bosomed maidens, blond-haired,

6590.55.text:
vital, sunburnt, carefree — existed and

6597.16.text:

6602.11.text:

6608.18.text:

swift scuttling movements, and fat inscrutable

6613.57.text:
faces with very small eyes. It was the type

6630.83.text: took his pipe out of his mouth.

6632.58.text:
'The Ministry of Plenty's certainly done a

6636.58.text:

6643.54.text:
'Not one,' said Winston. 'I've been using

6647.87.text:
'Ah, well — just thought I'd ask you, old

6654.80.text:
The quacking voice from the next table, temporarily
silenced during the Ministry's announcement,

6659.25.text:
had started up again, as loud as ever. For
some reason Winston suddenly found himself

6663.86.text:
thinking of Mrs. Parsons, with her wispy hair
and the dust in the creases of her face. Within

6670.32.text:
two years those children would be denouncing
her to the Thought Police. Mrs. Parsons would

6674.69.text:
be vaporized. Syme would be vaporized. Winston

6682.56.text:
Parsons, on the other hand, would never be

6686.70.text:
voice would never be vaporized. The little
beetle-like men who scuttle so nimbly through

6691.60.text:

6696.55.text:
with dark hair, the girl from the Fiction
Department — she would never be vaporized

6701.02.text:

6706.01.text:
just what it was that made for survival, it

6712.19.text:
At this moment he was dragged out of his reverie

6717.15.text:
table had turned partly round and was looking

6722.69.text:
was looking at him in a sidelong way, but
with curious intensity. The instant she caught

6727.96.text: his eye she looked away again.

6730.16.text:
The sweat started out on Winston's backbone.
A horrible pang of terror went through him.

6735.49.text:
It was gone almost at once, but it left a
sort of nagging uneasiness behind. Why was

6739.88.text:
she watching him? Why did she keep following
him about? Unfortunately he could not remember

6746.02.text:
whether she had already been at the table
when he arrived, or had come there afterwards.

6750.43.text:
But yesterday, at any rate, during the Two
Minutes Hate, she had sat immediately behind

6754.60.text:
him when there was no apparent need to do
so. Quite likely her real object had been

6760.04.text:
to listen to him and make sure whether he

6764.05.text:
His earlier thought returned to him: probably

6768.74.text:
Police, but then it was precisely the amateur

6775.13.text:
did not know how long she had been looking
at him, but perhaps for as much as five minutes,

6780.87.text:
and it was possible that his features had
not been perfectly under control. It was terribly

6785.32.text:
dangerous to let your thoughts wander when
you were in any public place or within range

6789.13.text:
of a telescreen. The smallest thing could
give you away. A nervous tic, an unconscious

6795.10.text:
look of anxiety, a habit of muttering to yourself
— anything that carried with it the suggestion

6800.32.text:
of abnormality, of having something to hide.
In any case, to wear an improper expression

6805.49.text:
on your face (to look incredulous when a victory
was announced, for example) was itself a punishable

6810.65.text:
offence. There was even a word for it in Newspeak:

6817.25.text:
The girl had turned her back on him again.
Perhaps after all she was not really following

6822.25.text:
him about, perhaps it was coincidence that
she had sat so close to him two days running.

6828.61.text:
His cigarette had gone out, and he laid it
carefully on the edge of the table. He would

6833.38.text:
finish smoking it after work, if he could
keep the tobacco in it. Quite likely the person

6838.12.text:
at the next table was a spy of the Thought
Police, and quite likely he would be in the

6843.26.text:
cellars of the Ministry of Love within three
days, but a cigarette end must not be wasted.

when those two nippers of mine set fire to

saw her wrapping up sausages in a poster of

it with a box of matches. Burned her quite

keen as mustard! That's a first-rate training

It was three years ago. It was on a dark evening,

6917.20.text:

hardly gave any light. She had a young face,

6929.88.text:
that appealed to me, the whiteness of it,

6934.23.text:
women never paint their faces. There was nobody

6944.44.text:
For the moment it was too difficult to go

6948.56.text:

6953.81.text:

6958.49.text:
against the wall, to kick over the table,

6962.10.text:
do any violent or noisy or painful thing that

6968.79.text:
Your worst enemy, he reflected, was your own

6974.12.text:
inside you was liable to translate itself

6979.24.text:
man whom he had passed in the street a few

6983.59.text:
a Party member, aged thirty-five to forty,

6989.35.text:
were a few metres apart when the left side
of the man's face was suddenly contorted by

6993.88.text:
a sort of spasm. It happened again just as
they were passing one another: it was only

6998.64.text:
a twitch, a quiver, rapid as the clicking
of a camera shutter, but obviously habitual.

7005.00.text:
He remembered thinking at the time: That poor

7010.78.text:
was that the action was quite possibly unconscious.
The most deadly danger of all was talking

7016.40.text:
in your sleep. There was no way of guarding

7020.10.text: He drew his breath and went on writing:

7024.38.text:
I went with her through the doorway and across
a backyard into a basement kitchen. There

7030.87.text:
was a bed against the wall, and a lamp on
the table, turned down very low. She —

7036.03.text:
His teeth were set on edge. He would have
liked to spit. Simultaneously with the woman

7041.35.text:
in the basement kitchen he thought of Katharine,
his wife. Winston was married — had been

7046.33.text:
married, at any rate: probably he still was

7050.20.text:
dead. He seemed to breathe again the warm
stuffy odour of the basement kitchen, an odour

7055.75.text:
compounded of bugs and dirty clothes and villainous

7061.96.text:
no woman of the Party ever used scent, or
could be imagined as doing so. Only the proles

7067.28.text:
used scent. In his mind the smell of it was
inextricably mixed up with fornication.

7074.13.text:
When he had gone with that woman it had been
his first lapse in two years or thereabouts.

7078.80.text:
Consorting with prostitutes was forbidden,
of course, but it was one of those rules that

7082.50.text:
you could occasionally nerve yourself to break.
It was dangerous, but it was not a life-and-death

7087.73.text:
matter. To be caught with a prostitute might
mean five years in a forced-labour camp: not

7092.68.text:
more, if you had committed no other offence.
And it was easy enough, provided that you

7097.54.text:
could avoid being caught in the act. The poorer
quarters swarmed with women who were ready

7101.84.text:
to sell themselves. Some could even be purchased
for a bottle of gin, which the proles were

7106.32.text:
not supposed to drink. Tacitly the Party was
even inclined to encourage prostitution, as

7111.79.text:
an outlet for instincts which could not be
altogether suppressed. Mere debauchery did

7117.27.text:
not matter very much, so long as it was furtive
and joyless and only involved the women of

7122.08.text:
a submerged and despised class. The unforgivable
crime was promiscuity between Party members.

7129.45.text:
But — though this was one of the crimes
that the accused in the great purges invariably

7133.25.text:
confessed to — it was difficult to imagine
any such thing actually happening.

7138.64.text:
The aim of the Party was not merely to prevent
men and women from forming loyalties which

7142.80.text:
it might not be able to control. Its real,
undeclared purpose was to remove all pleasure

7148.29.text:
from the sexual act. Not love so much as eroticism
was the enemy, inside marriage as well as

7155.07.text:
outside it. All marriages between Party members
had to be approved by a committee appointed

7159.99.text:
for the purpose, and — though the principle
was never clearly stated — permission was

7164.71.text:
always refused if the couple concerned gave
the impression of being physically attracted

7168.87.text:
to one another. The only recognized purpose
of marriage was to beget children for the

7173.99.text:
service of the Party. Sexual intercourse was
to be looked on as a slightly disgusting minor

7179.31.text:
operation, like having an enema. This again
was never put into plain words, but in an

7185.48.text:
indirect way it was rubbed into every Party
member from childhood onwards. There were

7190.22.text:
even organizations such as the Junior Anti-Sex
League, which advocated complete celibacy

7195.39.text:
for both sexes. All children were to be begotten
by artificial insemination (artsem, it was

7201.89.text:
called in Newspeak) and brought up in public
institutions. This, Winston was aware, was

7206.77.text:
not meant altogether seriously, but somehow
it fitted in with the general ideology of

7210.80.text:
the Party. The Party was trying to kill the
sex instinct, or, if it could not be killed,

7216.51.text:
then to distort it and dirty it. He did not
know why this was so, but it seemed natural

7221.60.text:
that it should be so. And as far as the women
were concerned, the Party's efforts were largely

7227.70.text:
He thought again of Katharine. It must be
nine, ten — nearly eleven years since they

7233.83.text:
had parted. It was curious how seldom he thought
of her. For days at a time he was capable

7238.99.text:
of forgetting that he had ever been married.
They had only been together for about fifteen

7243.64.text:
months. The Party did not permit divorce,
but it rather encouraged separation in cases

7250.95.text:
Katharine was a tall, fair-haired girl, very
straight, with splendid movements. She had

7256.27.text:
a bold, aquiline face, a face that one might
have called noble until one discovered that

7261.08.text:
there was as nearly as possible nothing behind
it. Very early in her married life he had

7265.96.text:
decided — though perhaps it was only that
he knew her more intimately than he knew most

7269.65.text:
people — that she had without exception
the most stupid, vulgar, empty mind that he

7274.60.text:
had ever encountered. She had not a thought
in her head that was not a slogan, and there

7278.81.text:
was no imbecility, absolutely none that she
was not capable of swallowing if the Party

7283.48.text:
handed it out to her. 'The human sound-track'
he nicknamed her in his own mind. Yet he could

7288.82.text:
have endured living with her if it had not
been for just one thing — sex.

7294.37.text:
As soon as he touched her she seemed to wince
and stiffen. To embrace her was like embracing

7299.86.text:
a jointed wooden image. And what was strange
was that even when she was clasping him against

7305.55.text:

7311.12.text:

that impression. She would lie there with

7314.56.text:

7321.02.text:
and, after a while, horrible. But even then
he could have borne living with her if it

7325.86.text:
had been agreed that they should remain celibate.
But curiously enough it was Katharine who

7330.56.text:
refused this. They must, she said, produce
a child if they could. So the performance

7336.14.text:
continued to happen, once a week quite regulariy,

7341.57.text:

which had to be done that evening and which

7345.17.text:
must not be forgotten. She had two names for

7357.54.text:

7362.44.text:
no child appeared, and in the end she agreed

She threw herself down on the bed, and at
once, without any kind of preliminary in the

7379.26.text:
most coarse, horrible way you can imagine,
pulled up her skirt. I —

7383.76.text:
He saw himself standing there in the dim lamplight,

7388.57.text:
his nostrils, and in his heart a feeling of
defeat and resentment which even at that moment

7393.06.text:
was mixed up with the thought of Katharine's

7397.85.text:
power of the Party. Why did it always have
to be like this? Why could he not have a woman

7404.45.text:
of his own instead of these filthy scuffles

7410.65.text:
was an almost unthinkable event. The women
of the Party were all alike. Chastity was

7416.42.text:
as deep ingrained in them as Party loyalty.
By careful early conditioning, by games and

7422.17.text:
cold water, by the rubbish that was dinned

7426.77.text:
Youth League, by lectures, parades, songs,

7431.78.text:

7438.01.text:

7444.06.text:
And what he wanted, more even than to be loved,
was to break down that wall of virtue, even

7448.87.text:
if it were only once in his whole life. The
sexual act, successfully performed, was rebellion.

7456.75.text:
Desire was thoughtcrime. Even to have awakened

7461.58.text:
have been like a seduction, although she was
his wife.

7463.95.text:
But the rest of the story had got to be written

7467.74.text:
I turned up the lamp. When I saw her in the
light —

7471.70.text:
After the darkness the feeble light of the
paraffin lamp had seemed very bright. For

7475.49.text:
the first time he could see the woman properly.
He had taken a step towards her and then halted,

7480.95.text:
full of lust and terror. He was painfully

7486.19.text:

7490.57.text:
they might be waiting outside the door at
this moment. If he went away without even

7494.64.text: doing what he had come here to do—!

7496.79.text:
It had got to be written down, it had got
to be confessed. What he had suddenly seen

7502.24.text:
in the lamplight was that the woman was old.
The paint was plastered so thick on her face

7507.70.text:
that it looked as though it might crack like

7512.80.text:

7517.40.text:

7522.21.text: He wrote hurriedly, in scrabbling handwriting:

7525.42.text:
When I saw her in the light she was quite
an old woman, fifty years old at least. But

7529.89.text: I went ahead and did it just the same.

7533.51.text:
He pressed his fingers against his eyelids

7538.66.text:
it made no difference. The therapy had not
worked. The urge to shout filthy words at

7544.59.text: the top of his voice was as strong as ever.

7548.49.text:
If there is hope, wrote Winston, it lies in
the proles.

7555.39.text:
If there was hope, it must lie in the proles,
because only there in those swarming disregarded

7560.93.text:
masses, 85 per cent of the population of Oceania,
could the force to destroy the Party ever

7566.25.text:
be generated. The Party could not be overthrown

7572.93.text:

7584.15.text:

Rebellion meant a look in the eyes, an inflexion

7590.09.text:

7596.19.text:
become conscious of their own strength. would
have no need to conspire. They needed only

7601.39.text:
to rise up and shake themselves like a horse

7606.41.text:
blow the Party to pieces tomorrow morning.
Surely sooner or later it must occur to them

7614.41.text:
He remembered how once he had been walking
down a crowded street when a tremendous shout

7618.75.text:
of hundreds of voices women's voices — had
burst from a side-street a little way ahead.

7623.93.text:
It was a great formidable cry of anger and

7630.55.text:
went humming on like the reverberation of
a bell. His heart had leapt. It's started!

7635.10.text:
he had thought. A riot! The proles are breaking

7640.09.text:
it was to see a mob of two or three hundred

7644.19.text:
market, with faces as tragic as though they

7648.80.text:
ship. But at this moment the general despair

7654.16.text:
quarrels. It appeared that one of the stalls

7659.96.text:
wretched, flimsy things, but cooking-pots

7663.88.text:
Now the supply had unexpectedly given out.
The successful women, bumped and jostled by

7669.69.text:
the rest, were trying to make off with their
saucepans while dozens of others clamoured

7673.75.text:
round the stall, accusing the stall-keeper
of favouritism and of having more saucepans

7678.11.text:
somewhere in reserve. There was a fresh outburst

7683.27.text:
her hair coming down, had got hold of the
same saucepan and were trying to tear it out

7687.21.text:
of one another's hands. For a moment they
were both tugging, and then the handle came

7691.88.text:
off. Winston watched them disgustedly. And
yet, just for a moment, what almost frightening

7700.05.text:
power had sounded in that cry from only a
few hundred throats! Why was it that they

7705.64.text:
could never shout like that about anything
that mattered?

7709.59.text:
Until they become conscious they will never
rebel, and until after they have rebelled

7716.53.text:
That, he reflected, might almost have been
a transcription from one of the Party textbooks.

7722.31.text:
The Party claimed, of course, to have liberated
the proles from bondage. Before the Revolution

7727.11.text:
they had been hideously oppressed by the capitalists,
they had been starved and flogged, women had

7731.82.text:
been forced to work in the coal mines (women
still did work in the coal mines, as a matter

7736.11.text:
of fact), children had been sold into the
factories at the age of six. But simultaneously,

7741.02.text:
true to the Principles of doublethink, the
Party taught that the proles were natural

7744.81.text:
inferiors who must be kept in subjection,
like animals, by the application of a few

7749.49.text:
simple rules. In reality very little was known
about the proles. It was not necessary to

7755.57.text:
know much. So long as they continued to work
and breed, their other activities were without

7760.58.text:
importance. Left to themselves, like cattle
turned loose upon the plains of Argentina,

7766.13.text:
they had reverted to a style of life that
appeared to be natural to them, a sort of

7769.55.text:
ancestral pattern. They were born, they grew
up in the gutters, they went to work at twelve,

7774.99.text:
they passed through a brief blossoming-period
of beauty and sexual desire, they married

7779.85.text:
at twenty, they were middle-aged at thirty,
they died, for the most part, at sixty. Heavy

7784.24.text:
physical work, the care of home and children,
petty quarrels with neighbours, films, football,

7789.45.text:
beer, and above all, gambling, filled up the
horizon of their minds. To keep them in control

7795.20.text:
was not difficult. A few agents of the Thought
Police moved always among them, spreading

7800.84.text:
false rumours and marking down and eliminating
the few individuals who were judged capable

7805.43.text:
of becoming dangerous; but no attempt was
made to indoctrinate them with the ideology

7809.85.text:
of the Party. It was not desirable that the
proles should have strong political feelings.

7815.66.text:
All that was required of them was a primitive
patriotism which could be appealed to whenever

7820.10.text:
it was necessary to make them accept longer
working-hours or shorter rations. And even

7825.14.text:
when they became discontented, as they sometimes
did, their discontent led nowhere, because

7830.34.text:
being without general ideas, they could only
focus it on petty specific grievances. The

7835.60.text:
larger evils invariably escaped their notice.
The great majority of proles did not even

7840.18.text:
have telescreens in their homes. Even the
civil police interfered with them very little.

7845.35.text:
There was a vast amount of criminality in
London, a whole world-within-a-world of thieves,
