9204.37.text:
People were shooting into the doorways like
rabbits. A young woman leapt out of a doorway

9208.35.text:
a little ahead of Winston, grabbed up a tiny
child playing in a puddle, whipped her apron

9212.55.text:
round it, and leapt back again, all in one
movement. At the same instant a man in a concertina-like

9217.97.text:
black suit, who had emerged from a side alley,
ran towards Winston, pointing excitedly to

9223.43.text:
'Steamer!' he yelled. 'Look out, guv'nor!
Bang over'ead! Lay down quick!'

9227.10.text:
'Steamer' was a nickname which, for some reason,
the proles applied to rocket bombs. Winston

9232.04.text:
promptly flung himself on his face. The proles
were nearly always right when they gave you

9236.20.text:
a warning of this kind. They seemed to possess
some kind of instinct which told them several

9240.55.text:
seconds in advance when a rocket was coming,
although the rockets supposedly travelled

9244.61.text:
faster than sound. Winston clasped his forearms
above his head. There was a roar that seemed

9250.01.text:
to make the pavement heave; a shower of light
objects pattered on to his back. When he stood

9255.51.text:
up he found that he was covered with fragments
of glass from the nearest window.

9259.84.text:
He walked on. The bomb had demolished a group
of houses 200 metres up the street. A black

9266.69.text:
plume of smoke hung in the sky, and below
it a cloud of plaster dust in which a crowd

9271.41.text:
was already forming around the ruins. There
was a little pile of plaster lying on the

9275.54.text:
pavement ahead of him, and in the middle of
it he could see a bright red streak. When

9279.96.text:
he got up to it he saw that it was a human
hand severed at the wrist. Apart from the

9284.82.text:
bloody stump, the hand was so completely whitened
as to resemble a plaster cast.

9290.40.text:
He kicked the thing into the gutter, and then,
to avoid the crowd, turned down a side-street

9294.36.text:
to the right. Within three or four minutes
he was out of the area which the bomb had

9298.91.text:
affected, and the sordid swarming life of
the streets was going on as though nothing

9303.16.text:
had happened. It was nearly twenty hours,
and the drinking-shops which the proles frequented

9308.69.text:
('pubs', they called them) were choked with
customers. From their grimy swing doors, endlessly

9314.09.text:
opening and shutting, there came forth a smell
of urine, sawdust, and sour beer. In an angle

9320.24.text:
formed by a projecting house-front three men
were standing very close together, the middle

9324.59.text:
one of them holding a folded-up newspaper
which the other two were studying over his

9328.65.text:
shoulder. Even before he was near enough to
make out the expression on their faces, Winston

9332.87.text:
could see absorption in every line of their
bodies. It was obviously some serious piece

9337.75.text:
of news that they were reading. He was a few
paces away from them when suddenly the group

9341.94.text:
broke up and two of the men were in violent
altercation. For a moment they seemed almost

9347.96.text:
'Can't you bleeding well listen to what I
say? I tell you no number ending in seven

9351.08.text: ain't won for over fourteen months!'

9354.59.text:
'No, it 'as not! Back 'ome I got the 'ole
lot of 'em for over two years wrote down on

9358.97.text:
a piece of paper. I takes 'em down reg'lar
as the clock. An" I tell you, no number ending

9364.79.text:
'Yes, a seven 'as won! I could pretty near
tell you the bleeding number. Four oh seven,

9370.03.text:
it ended in. It were in February — second
week in February.'

9373.16.text:
'February your grandmother! I got it all down
in black and white. An" I tell you, no number—'

9377.81.text: 'Oh, pack it in!' said the third man.

9381.63.text:
They were talking about the Lottery. Winston
looked back when he had gone thirty metres.

9385.95.text:
They were still arguing, with vivid, passionate
faces. The Lottery, with its weekly pay-out

9391.32.text:
of enormous prizes, was the one public event
to which the proles paid serious attention.

9395.98.text:
It was probable that there were some millions
of proles for whom the Lottery was the principal

9400.63.text:
if not the only reason for remaining alive.
It was their delight, their folly, their anodyne,

9406.62.text:
their intellectual stimulant. Where the Lottery
was concerned, even people who could barely

9410.94.text:
read and write seemed capable of intricate
calculations and staggering feats of memory.

9416.23.text:
There was a whole tribe of men who made a
living simply by selling systems, forecasts,

9420.37.text:
and lucky amulets. Winston had nothing to
do with the running of the Lottery, which

9424.47.text:
was managed by the Ministry of Plenty, but
he was aware (indeed everyone in the party

9428.72.text:
was aware) that the prizes were largely imaginary.
Only small sums were actually paid out, the

9434.33.text:
winners of the big prizes being non-existent
persons. In the absence of any real intercommunication

9439.97.text:
between one part of Oceania and another, this
was not difficult to arrange.

9444.41.text:
But if there was hope, it lay in the proles.
You had to cling on to that. When you put

9451.38.text:
it in words it sounded reasonable: it was
when you looked at the human beings passing

9455.96.text:
you on the pavement that it became an act
of faith. The street into which he had turned

9460.80.text:
ran downhill. He had a feeling that he had
been in this neighbourhood before, and that

9465.38.text:
there was a main thoroughfare not far away.
From somewhere ahead there came a din of shouting

9470.78.text:
voices. The street took a sharp turn and then
ended in a flight of steps which led down

9475.00.text:
into a sunken alley where a few stall-keepers
were selling tired-looking vegetables. At

9480.69.text:
this moment Winston remembered where he was.
The alley led out into the main street, and

9486.64.text:
down the next turning, not five minutes away,
was the junk-shop where he had bought the

9490.39.text:
blank book which was now his diary. And in
a small stationer's shop not far away he had

9495.29.text: bought his penholder and his bottle of ink.

9498.21.text:
He paused for a moment at the top of the steps.
On the opposite side of the alley there was

9503.08.text:
a dingy little pub whose windows appeared
to be frosted over but in reality were merely

9507.59.text:
coated with dust. A very old man, bent but
active, with white moustaches that bristled

9514.52.text:
forward like those of a prawn, pushed open
the swing door and went in. As Winston stood

9519.92.text:
watching, it occurred to him that the old
man, who must be eighty at the least, had

9524.06.text:
already been middle-aged when the Revolution
happened. He and a few others like him were

9529.08.text:
the last links that now existed with the vanished
world of capitalism. In the Party itself there

9535.65.text:
were not many people left whose ideas had
been formed before the Revolution. The older

9540.18.text:
generation had mostly been wiped out in the
great purges of the fifties and sixties, and

9544.52.text:
the few who survived had long ago been terrified
into complete intellectual surrender. If there

9550.47.text:
was any one still alive who could give you
a truthful account of conditions in the early

9553.92.text:
part of the century, it could only be a prole.
Suddenly the passage from the history book

9559.47.text:
that he had copied into his diary came back
into Winston's mind, and a lunatic impulse

9564.24.text:
took hold of him. He would go into the pub,
he would scrape acquaintance with that old

9569.63.text:
man and question him. He would say to him:
'Tell me about your life when you were a boy.

9574.16.text:
What was it like in those days? Were things
better than they are now, or were they worse?'

9578.09.text:
Hurriedly, lest he should have time to become
frightened, he descended the steps and crossed

9582.29.text:
the narrow street. It was madness of course.
As usual, there was no definite rule against

9587.00.text:
talking to proles and frequenting their pubs,
but it was far too unusual an action to pass

9592.25.text:
unnoticed. If the patrols appeared he might
plead an attack of faintness, but it was not

9596.87.text:
likely that they would believe him. He pushed
open the door, and a hideous cheesy smell

9602.25.text:
of sour beer hit him in the face. As he entered
the din of voices dropped to about half its

9607.96.text:
volume. Behind his back he could feel everyone
eyeing his blue overalls. A game of darts

9614.78.text:
which was going on at the other end of the
room interrupted itself for perhaps as much

9618.04.text:
as thirty seconds. The old man whom he had
followed was standing at the bar, having some

9623.26.text:
kind of altercation with the barman, a large,
stout, hook-nosed young man with enormous

9628.26.text:
forearms. A knot of others, standing round
with glasses in their hands, were watching

9633.34.text:
'I arst you civil enough, didn't I?' said
the old man, straightening his shoulders pugnaciously.

9639.13.text:
'You telling me you ain't got a pint mug in
the 'ole bleeding boozer?'

9642.61.text:
'And what in hell's name is a pint?' said
the barman, leaning forward with the tips

9647.71.text: of his fingers on the counter.

9649.16.text:
'Ark at 'im! Calls 'isself a barman and don't
know what a pint is! Why, a pint's the 'alf

9654.89.text:
of a quart, and there's four quarts to the
gallon. 'Ave to teach you the A, B, C next.'

9659.37.text:
'Never heard of 'em,' said the barman shortly.
'Litre and half litre — that's all we serve.

9664.88.text:
There's the glasses on the shelf in front
of you.'

9667.08.text:
'I likes a pint,' persisted the old man. 'You
could 'a drawed me off a pint easy enough.

9672.59.text:
We didn't 'ave these bleeding litres when
I was a young man.'

9676.35.text:
'When you were a young man we were all living
in the treetops,' said the barman, with a

9682.71.text:
There was a shout of laughter, and the uneasiness
caused by Winston's entry seemed to disappear.

9687.70.text:
The old man's whitestubbled face had flushed
pink. He turned away, muttering to himself,

9692.64.text:
and bumped into Winston. Winston caught him
gently by the arm.

9696.11.text: 'May I offer you a drink?' he said.

9699.12.text:
'You're a gent,' said the other, straightening
his shoulders again. He appeared not to have

9704.63.text:
noticed Winston's blue overalls. 'Pint!' he
added aggressively to the barman. 'Pint of

9711.67.text:
The barman swished two half-litres of dark-brown
beer into thick glasses which he had rinsed

9716.29.text:
in a bucket under the counter. Beer was the
only drink you could get in prole pubs. The

9721.47.text:
proles were supposed not to drink gin, though
in practice they could get hold of it easily

9724.79.text:
enough. The game of darts was in full swing
again, and the knot of men at the bar had

9729.09.text:
begun talking about lottery tickets. Winston's
presence was forgotten for a moment. There

9734.84.text:
was a deal table under the window where he
and the old man could talk without fear of

9738.42.text:
being overheard. It was horribly dangerous,
but at any rate there was no telescreen in

9743.70.text:
the room, a point he had made sure of as soon
as he came in.

9746.79.text:
''E could 'a drawed me off a pint,' grumbled
the old man as he settled down behind a glass.

9751.82.text:
'A 'alf litre ain't enough. It don't satisfy.
And a 'ole litre's too much. It starts my

9756.58.text: bladder running. Let alone the price.'

9760.30.text:
'You must have seen great changes since you
were a young man,' said Winston tentatively.

9765.85.text:
The old man's pale blue eyes moved from the
darts board to the bar, and from the bar to

9771.12.text:
the door of the Gents, as though it were in
the bar-room that he expected the changes

9776.49.text:
'The beer was better,' he said finally. 'And
cheaper! When I was a young man, mild beer

9781.83.text:
— wallop we used to call it — was fourpence
a pint. That was before the war, of course.'

9789.02.text:
'It's all wars,' said the old man vaguely.
He took up his glass, and his shoulders straightened

9795.20.text:
again. ''Ere's wishing you the very best of
'ealth!'

9797.90.text:
In his lean throat the sharp-pointed Adam's
apple made a surprisingly rapid up-and-down

9803.21.text:
movement, and the beer vanished. Winston went
to the bar and came back with two more half-litres.

9809.51.text:
The old man appeared to have forgotten his
prejudice against drinking a full litre.

9813.53.text:
'You are very much older than I am,' said
Winston. 'You must have been a grown man before

9819.04.text:
I was born. You can remember what it was like
in the old days, before the Revolution. People

9825.49.text:
of my age don't really know anything about
those times. We can only read about them in

9830.41.text:
books, and what it says in the books may not
be true. I should like your opinion on that.

9836.10.text:
The history books say that life before the
Revolution was completely different from what

9840.29.text:
it is now. There was the most terrible oppression,
injustice, poverty worse than anything we

9845.30.text:
can imagine. Here in London, the great mass
of the people never had enough to eat from

9849.36.text:
birth to death. Half of them hadn't even boots
on their feet. They worked twelve hours a

9853.71.text:
day, they left school at nine, they slept
ten in a room. And at the same time there

9858.29.text:
were a very few people, only a few thousands
— the capitalists, they were called — who

9863.11.text:
were rich and powerful. They owned everything
that there was to own. They lived in great

9867.59.text:
gorgeous houses with thirty servants, they
rode about in motor-cars and four-horse carriages,

9872.65.text: they drank champagne, they wore top hats—'

9877.35.text:
'Top 'ats!' he said. 'Funny you should mention
'em. The same thing come into my 'ead only

9883.77.text:
yesterday, I dono why. I was jest thinking,
I ain't seen a top 'at in years. Gorn right

9889.21.text:
out, they 'ave. The last time I wore one was
at my sister-in-law's funeral. And that was

9894.30.text:
— well, I couldn't give you the date, but
it must'a been fifty years ago. Of course

9899.32.text: it was only 'ired for the occasion, you understand.'

9902.62.text:
'It isn't very important about the top hats,'
said Winston patiently. 'The point is, these

9908.56.text:
capitalists — they and a few lawyers and
priests and so forth who lived on them — were

9912.88.text:
the lords of the earth. Everything existed
for their benefit. You — the ordinary people,

9918.72.text:
the workers — were their slaves. They could
do what they liked with you. They could ship

9922.41.text:
you off to Canada like cattle. They could
sleep with your daughters if they chose. They

9926.55.text:
could order you to be flogged with something
called a cat-o'-nine tails. You had to take

9931.13.text:
your cap off when you passed them. Every capitalist
went about with a gang of lackeys who—'

9937.89.text:
'Lackeys!' he said. 'Now there's a word I
ain't 'eard since ever so long. Lackeys! That

9944.32.text:
reg'lar takes me back, that does. I recollect
oh, donkey's years ago — I used to sometimes

9949.31.text:
go to 'Yde Park of a Sunday afternoon to 'ear
the blokes making speeches. Salvation Army,

9954.89.text:
Roman Catholics, Jews, Indians — all sorts
there was. And there was one bloke — well,

9959.44.text:
I couldn't give you 'is name, but a real powerful
speaker 'e was. 'E didn't 'alf give it 'em!

9964.50.text:
"Lackeys!" 'e says, "lackeys of the bourgeoisie!
Flunkies of the ruling class!" Parasites — that

9969.61.text:
was another of them. And 'yenas — 'e definitely
called 'em 'yenas. Of course 'e was referring

9974.88.text: to the Labour Party, you understand.'

9977.86.text:
Winston had the feeling that they were talking
at cross-purposes.

9980.41.text:
'What I really wanted to know was this,' he
said. 'Do you feel that you have more freedom

9986.80.text:
now than you had in those days? Are you treated
more like a human being? In the old days,

9992.79.text: the rich people, the people at the top—'

9994.71.text: 'The 'Ouse of Lords,' put in the old man reminiscently.

9999.45.text:
'The House of Lords, if you like. What I am
asking is, were these people able to treat

10004.83.text:
you as an inferior, simply because they were
rich and you were poor? Is it a fact, for

10010.71.text:
instance, that you had to call them "Sir"
and take off your cap when you passed them?'

10014.91.text:
The old man appeared to think deeply. He drank
off about a quarter of his beer before answering.

10020.06.text:
'Yes,' he said. 'They liked you to touch your
cap to 'em. It showed respect, like. I didn't

10026.55.text:
agree with it, myself, but I done it often
enough. Had to, as you might say.'

10031.33.text:
'And was it usual — I'm only quoting what
I've read in history books — was it usual

10036.89.text:
for these people and their servants to push
you off the pavement into the gutter?'

10040.30.text:
'One of 'em pushed me once,' said the old
man. 'I recollect it as if it was yesterday.

10047.00.text:
It was Boat Race night — terribly rowdy
they used to get on Boat Race night — and

10051.12.text:
I bumps into a young bloke on Shaftesbury
Avenue. Quite a gent, 'e was — dress shirt,

10056.74.text:
top 'at, black overcoat. 'E was kind of zig-zagging
across the pavement, and I bumps into 'im

10061.54.text:
accidental-like. 'E says, "Why can't you look
where you're going?" 'e says. I say, "Ju think

10067.10.text:
you've bought the bleeding pavement?" 'E says,
"I'll twist your bloody 'ead off if you get

10071.08.text:
fresh with me." I says, "You're drunk. I'll
give you in charge in 'alf a minute," I says.

10075.89.text:
An' if you'll believe me, 'e puts 'is 'and
on my chest and gives me a shove as pretty

10080.23.text:
near sent me under the wheels of a bus. Well,
I was young in them days, and I was going

10088.52.text:
A sense of helplessness took hold of Winston.
The old man's memory was nothing but a rubbish-heap

10093.98.text:
of details. One could question him all day
without getting any real information. The

10098.69.text:
party histories might still be true, after
a fashion: they might even be completely true.

10105.71.text:
'Perhaps I have not made myself clear,' he
said. 'What I'm trying to say is this. You

10110.36.text:
have been alive a very long time; you lived
half your life before the Revolution. In 1925,

10116.49.text:
for instance, you were already grown up. Would
you say from what you can remember, that life

10123.15.text:
in 1925 was better than it is now, or worse?
If you could choose, would you prefer to live

10131.75.text:
The old man looked meditatively at the darts
board. He finished up his beer, more slowly

10136.87.text:
than before. When he spoke it was with a tolerant
philosophical air, as though the beer had

10144.56.text:
'I know what you expect me to say,' he said.
'You expect me to say as I'd sooner be young

10152.08.text:
again. Most people'd say they'd sooner be
young, if you arst" 'em. You got your 'ealth

10157.29.text:
and strength when you're young. When you get
to my time of life you ain't never well. I

10163.72.text:
suffer something wicked from my feet, and
my bladder's jest terrible. Six and seven

10168.25.text:
times a night it 'as me out of bed. On the
other 'and, there's great advantages in being

10173.76.text:
a old man. You ain't got the same worries.
No truck with women, and that's a great thing.

10179.75.text:
I ain't 'ad a woman for near on thirty year,
if you'd credit it. Nor wanted to, what's

10187.38.text:
Winston sat back against the window-sill.
It was no use going on. He was about to buy

10192.75.text:
some more beer when the old man suddenly got
up and shuffled rapidly into the stinking

10196.81.text:
urinal at the side of the room. The extra
half-litre was already working on him. Winston

10203.46.text:
sat for a minute or two gazing at his empty
glass, and hardly noticed when his feet carried

10208.14.text:
him out into the street again. Within twenty
years at the most, he reflected, the huge

10213.50.text:
and simple question, 'Was life better before
the Revolution than it is now?' would have

10218.89.text:
ceased once and for all to be answerable.
But in effect it was unanswerable even now,

10224.39.text:
since the few scattered survivors from the
ancient world were incapable of comparing

10228.27.text:
one age with another. They remembered a million
useless things, a quarrel with a workmate,

10233.00.text:
a hunt for a lost bicycle pump, the expression
on a long-dead sister's face, the swirls of

10237.88.text:
dust on a windy morning seventy years ago:
but all the relevant facts were outside the

10243.20.text:
range of their vision. They were like the
ant, which can see small objects but not large

10248.93.text:
ones. And when memory failed and written records
were falsified — when that happened, the

10254.68.text:
claim of the Party to have improved the conditions
of human life had got to be accepted, because

10259.58.text:
there did not exist, and never again could
exist, any standard against which it could

10267.29.text:
At this moment his train of thought stopped
abruptly. He halted and looked up. He was

10271.96.text:
in a narrow street, with a few dark little
shops, interspersed among dwelling-houses.

10277.29.text:
Immediately above his head there hung three
discoloured metal balls which looked as if

10281.27.text:
they had once been gilded. He seemed to know
the place. Of course! He was standing outside

10287.68.text: the junk-shop where he had bought the diary.

10290.76.text:
A twinge of fear went through him. It had
been a sufficiently rash act to buy the book

10295.67.text:
in the beginning, and he had sworn never to
come near the place again. And yet the instant

10300.26.text:
that he allowed his thoughts to wander, his
feet had brought him back here of their own

10303.71.text:
accord. It was precisely against suicidal
impulses of this kind that he had hoped to

10308.87.text:
guard himself by opening the diary. At the
same time he noticed that although it was

10314.37.text:
nearly twenty-one hours the shop was still
open. With the feeling that he would be less

10319.06.text:
conspicuous inside than hanging about on the
pavement, he stepped through the doorway.

10324.54.text:
If questioned, he could plausibly say that
he was trying to buy razor blades.

10328.28.text:
The proprietor had just lighted a hanging
oil lamp which gave off an unclean but friendly

10333.67.text:
smell. He was a man of perhaps sixty, frail
and bowed, with a long, benevolent nose, and

10340.45.text:
mild eyes distorted by thick spectacles. His
hair was almost white, but his eyebrows were

10345.63.text:
bushy and still black. His spectacles, his
gentle, fussy movements, and the fact that

10351.63.text:
he was wearing an aged jacket of black velvet,
gave him a vague air of intellectuality, as

10356.95.text:
though he had been some kind of literary man,
or perhaps a musician. His voice was soft,

10361.78.text:
as though faded, and his accent less debased
than that of the majority of proles.

10367.50.text:
'I recognized you on the pavement,' he said
immediately. 'You're the gentleman that bought

10373.16.text:
the young lady's keepsake album. That was
a beautiful bit of paper, that was. Cream-laid,

10378.97.text:
it used to be called. There's been no paper
like that made for — oh, I dare say fifty

10385.74.text:
years.' He peered at Winston over the top
of his spectacles. 'Is there anything special

10390.31.text:
I can do for you? Or did you just want to
look round?'

10393.69.text:
'I was passing,' said Winston vaguely. 'I
just looked in. I don't want anything in particular.'

10400.00.text:
'It's just as well,' said the other, 'because
I don't suppose I could have satisfied you.'

10404.45.text:
He made an apologetic gesture with his softpalmed
hand. 'You see how it is; an empty shop, you

10411.13.text:
might say. Between you and me, the antique
trade's just about finished. No demand any

10417.57.text:
longer, and no stock either. Furniture, china,
glass it's all been broken up by degrees.

10423.67.text:
And of course the metal stuff's mostly been
melted down. I haven't seen a brass candlestick

10430.38.text:
The tiny interior of the shop was in fact
uncomfortably full, but there was almost nothing

10434.88.text:
in it of the slightest value. The floorspace
was very restricted, because all round the

10440.21.text:
walls were stacked innumerable dusty picture-frames.
In the window there were trays of nuts and

10446.19.text:
bolts, worn-out chisels, penknives with broken
blades, tarnished watches that did not even

10450.96.text:
pretend to be in going order, and other miscellaneous
rubbish. Only on a small table in the corner

10456.33.text:
was there a litter of odds and ends — lacquered
snuffboxes, agate brooches, and the like — which

10461.02.text:
looked as though they might include something
interesting. As Winston wandered towards the

10464.99.text:
table his eye was caught by a round, smooth
thing that gleamed softly in the lamplight,

10472.75.text:
It was a heavy lump of glass, curved on one
side, flat on the other, making almost a hemisphere.

10478.16.text:
There was a peculiar softness, as of rainwater,
in both the colour and the texture of the

10482.70.text:
glass. At the heart of it, magnified by the
curved surface, there was a strange, pink,

10487.90.text:
convoluted object that recalled a rose or
a sea anemone.

10494.54.text:
'That's coral, that is,' said the old man.
'It must have come from the Indian Ocean.

10500.22.text:
They used to kind of embed it in the glass.
That wasn't made less than a hundred years

10505.03.text: ago. More, by the look of it.'

10510.32.text:
'It is a beautiful thing,' said the other
appreciatively. 'But there's not many that'd

10515.50.text:
say so nowadays.' He coughed. 'Now, if it
so happened that you wanted to buy it, that'd

10522.31.text:
cost you four dollars. I can remember when
a thing like that would have fetched eight

10527.07.text:
pounds, and eight pounds was — well, I can't
work it out, but it was a lot of money. But

10532.89.text:
who cares about genuine antiques nowadays
even the few that's left?'

10537.26.text:
Winston immediately paid over the four dollars
and slid the coveted thing into his pocket.

10542.22.text:
What appealed to him about it was not so much
its beauty as the air it seemed to possess

10547.31.text:
of belonging to an age quite different from
the present one. The soft, rainwatery glass

10553.09.text:
was not like any glass that he had ever seen.
The thing was doubly attractive because of

10557.60.text:
its apparent uselessness, though he could
guess that it must once have been intended

10560.98.text:
as a paperweight. It was very heavy in his
pocket, but fortunately it did not make much

10565.49.text:
of a bulge. It was a queer thing, even a compromising
thing, for a Party member to have in his possession.

10572.66.text:
Anything old, and for that matter anything
beautiful, was always vaguely suspect. The

10577.67.text:
old man had grown noticeably more cheerful
after receiving the four dollars. Winston

10582.32.text:
realized that he would have accepted three
or even two.

10585.31.text:
'There's another room upstairs that you might
care to take a look at,' he said. 'There's

10590.55.text:
not much in it. Just a few pieces. We'll do
with a light if we're going upstairs.'

10595.91.text:
He lit another lamp, and, with bowed back,
led the way slowly up the steep and worn stairs

10601.16.text:
and along a tiny passage, into a room which
did not give on the street but looked out

10605.44.text:
on a cobbled yard and a forest of chimney-pots.
Winston noticed that the furniture was still

10611.01.text:
arranged as though the room were meant to
be lived in. There was a strip of carpet on

10614.93.text:
the floor, a picture or two on the walls,
and a deep, slatternly arm-chair drawn up

10619.76.text:
to the fireplace. An old-fashioned glass clock
with a twelve-hour face was ticking away on

10627.17.text:
the mantelpiece. Under the window, and occupying
nearly a quarter of the room, was an enormous

10630.53.text: bed with the mattress still on it.

10632.76.text:
'We lived here till my wife died,' said the
old man half apologetically. 'I'm selling

10639.89.text:
the furniture off by little and little. Now
that's a beautiful mahogany bed, or at least

10646.65.text:
it would be if you could get the bugs out
of it. But I dare say you'd find it a little

10652.31.text:
He was holdlng the lamp high up, so as to
illuminate the whole room, and in the warm

10657.93.text:
dim light the place looked curiously inviting.
The thought flitted through Winston's mind

10663.41.text:
that it would probably be quite easy to rent
the room for a few dollars a week, if he dared

10668.08.text:
to take the risk. It was a wild, impossible
notion, to be abandoned as soon as thought

10674.21.text:
of; but the room had awakened in him a sort
of nostalgia, a sort of ancestral memory.

10680.68.text:
It seemed to him that he knew exactly what
it felt like to sit in a room like this, in

10684.84.text:
an arm-chair beside an open fire with your
feet in the fender and a kettle on the hob;

10688.88.text:
utterly alone, utterly secure, with nobody
watching you, no voice pursuing you, no sound

10693.89.text:
except the singing of the kettle and the friendly
ticking of the clock.

10700.19.text:
'There's no telescreen!' he could not help
murmuring.

10701.99.text:
'Ah,' said the old man, 'I never had one of
those things. Too expensive. And I never seemed

10708.98.text:
to feel the need of it, somehow. Now that's
a nice gateleg table in the corner there.

10715.63.text:
Though of course you'd have to put new hinges
on it if you wanted to use the flaps.'

10720.43.text:
There was a small bookcase in the other corner,
and Winston had already gravitated towards

10724.43.text:
it. It contained nothing but rubbish. The
hunting-down and destruction of books had

10729.11.text:
been done with the same thoroughness in the
prole quarters as everywhere else. It was

10733.55.text:
very unlikely that there existed anywhere
in Oceania a copy of a book printed earlier

10737.71.text:
than 1960. The old man, still carrying the
lamp, was standing in front of a picture in

10743.02.text:
a rosewood frame which hung on the other side
of the fireplace, opposite the bed.

10747.99.text:
'Now, if you happen to be interested in old
prints at all—' he began delicately.

10754.29.text:
Winston came across to examine the picture.
It was a steel engraving of an oval building

10759.08.text:
with rectangular windows, and a small tower
in front. There was a railing running round

10764.46.text:
the building, and at the rear end there was
what appeared to be a statue. Winston gazed

10769.53.text:
at it for some moments. It seemed vaguely
familiar, though he did not remember the statue.

10774.76.text:
'The frame's fixed to the wall,' said the
old man, 'but I could unscrew it for you,

10781.79.text:
'I know that building,' said Winston finally.
'It's a ruin now. It's in the middle of the

10787.21.text: street outside the Palace of Justice.'

10788.73.text:
'That's right. Outside the Law Courts. It
was bombed in — oh, many years ago. It was

10795.38.text:
a church at one time, St. Clement's Danes,
its name was.' He smiled apologetically, as

10801.42.text:
though conscious of saying something slightly
ridiculous, and added: '"Oranges and lemons,"

10806.93.text: say the bells of St. Clement's!'

10811.17.text:
'Oh — "'Oranges and lemons,' say the bells
of St. Clement's." That was a rhyme we had

10815.80.text:
when I was a little boy. How it goes on I
don't remember, but I do know it ended up,

10821.46.text:
"Here comes a candle to light you to bed,
Here comes a chopper to chop off your head."

10826.77.text:
It was a kind of a dance. They held out their
arms for you to pass under, and when they

10831.14.text:
came to "Here comes a chopper to chop off
your head" they brought their arms down and

10834.95.text:
caught you. It was just names of churches.
All the London churches were in it — all

10842.88.text:
Winston wondered vaguely to what century the
church belonged. It was always difficult to

10847.15.text:
determine the age of a London building. Anything
large and impressive, if it was reasonably

10852.74.text:
new in appearance, was automatically claimed
as having been built since the Revolution,

10857.49.text:
while anything that was obviously of earlier
date was ascribed to some dim period called

10862.18.text:
the Middle Ages. The centuries of capitalism
were held to have produced nothing of any

10867.14.text:
value. One could not learn history from architecture
any more than one could learn it from books.

10872.18.text:
Statues, inscriptions, memorial stones, the
names of streets — anything that might throw

10876.59.text:
light upon the past had been systematically
altered.

10880.04.text: 'I never knew it had been a church,' he said.

10883.38.text:
'There's a lot of them left, really,' said
the old man, 'though they've been put to other

10888.43.text:
uses. Now, how did that rhyme go? Ah! I've
got it!

10894.14.text:
'Oranges and lemons,' say the bells of St.
Clement's,

10897.45.text:
'You owe me three farthings,' say the bells
of St. Martin's —

10901.79.text:
there, now, that's as far as I can get. A
farthing, that was a small copper coin, looked

10910.15.text:
'St. Martin's? That's still standing. It's
in Victory Square, alongside the picture gallery.

10915.09.text:
A building with a kind of a triangular porch
and pillars in front, and a big flight of

10921.70.text:
Winston knew the place well. It was a museum
used for propaganda displays of various kinds

10926.69.text:
— scale models of rocket bombs and Floating
Fortresses, waxwork tableaux illustrating

10934.10.text:
'St. Martin's-in-the-Fields it used to be
called,' supplemented the old man, 'though

10939.68.text:
I don't recollect any fields anywhere in those
parts.'

10944.47.text:
Winston did not buy the picture. It would
have been an even more incongruous possession

10948.42.text:
than the glass paperweight, and impossible
to carry home, unless it were taken out of

10951.72.text:
its frame. But he lingered for some minutes
more, talking to the old man, whose name,

10956.73.text:
he discovered, was not Weeks — as one might
have gathered from the inscription over the

10959.80.text:
shop-front — but Charrington. Mr. Charrington,
it seemed, was a widower aged sixty-three

10966.72.text:
and had inhabited this shop for thirty years.
Throughout that time he had been intending

10971.52.text:
to alter the name over the window, but had
never quite got to the point of doing it.

10976.10.text:
All the while that they were talking the half-remembered
rhyme kept running through Winston's head.

10980.52.text:
Oranges and lemons say the bells of St. Clement's,
You owe me three farthings, say the bells

10985.07.text:
of St. Martin's! It was curious, but when
you said it to yourself you had the illusion

10989.92.text:
of actually hearing bells, the bells of a
lost London that still existed somewhere or

10996.09.text:
other, disguised and forgotten. From one ghostly
steeple after another he seemed to hear them

11001.22.text:
pealing forth. Yet so far as he could remember
he had never in real life heard church bells

11009.31.text:
He got away from Mr. Charrington and went
down the stairs alone, so as not to let the

11013.12.text:
old man see him reconnoitring the street before
stepping out of the door. He had already made

11018.34.text:
up his mind that after a suitable interval
— a month, say — he would take the risk

11022.13.text:
of visiting the shop again. It was perhaps
not more dangerous than shirking an evening

11027.06.text:
at the Centre. The serious piece of folly
had been to come back here in the first place,

11031.76.text:
after buying the diary and without knowing
whether the proprietor of the shop could be

11037.89.text:
Yes, he thought again, he would come back.
He would buy further scraps of beautiful rubbish.

11044.61.text:
He would buy the engraving of St. Clement's
Danes, take it out of its frame, and carry

11048.15.text:
it home concealed under the jacket of his
overalls. He would drag the rest of that poem

11052.85.text:
out of Mr. Charrington's memory. Even the
lunatic project of renting the room upstairs

11057.52.text:
flashed momentarily through his mind again.
For perhaps five seconds exaltation made him

11062.76.text:
careless, and he stepped out on to the pavement
without so much as a preliminary glance through

11066.35.text:
the window. He had even started humming to
an improvised tune —

11070.05.text:
'Oranges and lemons,' say the bells of St.
Clement's,

11072.68.text: 'You owe me three farthings,' say the —

11074.68.text:
Suddenly his heart seemed to turn to ice and
his bowels to water. A figure in blue overalls

11080.97.text:
was coming down the pavement, not ten metres
away. It was the girl from the Fiction Department,

11085.35.text:
the girl with dark hair. The light was failing,
but there was no difficulty in recognizing

11090.02.text:
her. She looked him straight in the face,
then walked quickly on as though she had not

11096.77.text:
For a few seconds Winston was too paralysed
to move. Then he turned to the right and walked

11101.51.text:
heavily away, not noticing for the moment
that he was going in the wrong direction.

11106.18.text:
At any rate, one question was settled. There
was no doubting any longer that the girl was

11110.10.text:
spying on him. She must have followed him
here, because it was not credible that by

11115.06.text:
pure chance she should have happened to be
walking on the same evening up the same obscure

11119.12.text:
backstreet, kilometres distant from any quarter
where Party members lived. It was too great

11124.33.text:
a coincidence. Whether she was really an agent
of the Thought Police, or simply an amateur

11130.09.text:
spy actuated by officiousness, hardly mattered.
It was enough that she was watching him. Probably

11135.85.text: she had seen him go into the pub as well.

11138.01.text:
It was an effort to walk. The lump of glass
in his pocket banged against his thigh at

11143.24.text:
each step, and he was half minded to take
it out and throw it away. The worst thing

11147.83.text:
was the pain in his belly. For a couple of
minutes he had the feeling that he would die

11151.60.text:
if he did not reach a lavatory soon. But there
would be no public lavatories in a quarter

11156.13.text:
like this. Then the spasm passed, leaving
a dull ache behind.

11160.97.text:
The street was a blind alley. Winston halted,
stood for several seconds wondering vaguely

11166.18.text:
what to do, then turned round and began to
retrace his steps. As he turned it occurred

11172.30.text:
to him that the girl had only passed him three
minutes ago and that by running he could probably

11176.09.text:
catch up with her. He could keep on her track
till they were in some quiet place, and then

11180.26.text:
smash her skull in with a cobblestone. The
piece of glass in his pocket would be heavy

11184.75.text:
enough for the job. But he abandoned the idea
immediately, because even the thought of making

11189.32.text:
any physical effort was unbearable. He could
not run, he could not strike a blow. Besides,

11194.42.text:
she was young and lusty and would defend herself.
He thought also of hurrying to the Community

11198.89.text:
Centre and staying there till the place closed,
so as to establish a partial alibi for the

11203.56.text:
evening. But that too was impossible. A deadly
lassitude had taken hold of him. All he wanted

11210.35.text:
was to get home quickly and then sit down
and be quiet.

11215.66.text:
It was after twenty-two hours when he got
back to the flat. The lights would be switched

11219.64.text:
off at the main at twenty-three thirty. He
went into the kitchen and swallowed nearly

11224.70.text:
a teacupful of Victory Gin. Then he went to
the table in the alcove, sat down, and took

11229.95.text:
the diary out of the drawer. But he did not
open it at once. From the telescreen a brassy

11235.70.text:
female voice was squalling a patriotic song.
He sat staring at the marbled cover of the

11241.78.text:
book, trying without success to shut the voice
out of his consciousness.

11246.18.text:
It was at night that they came for you, always
at night. The proper thing was to kill yourself

11252.09.text:
before they got you. Undoubtedly some people
did so. Many of the disappearances were actually

11257.59.text:
suicides. But it needed desperate courage
to kill yourself in a world where firearms,

11263.06.text:
or any quick and certain poison, were completely
unprocurable. He thought with a kind of astonishment

11268.51.text:
of the biological uselessness of pain and
fear, the treachery of the human body which

11273.29.text:
always freezes into inertia at exactly the
moment when a special effort is needed. He

11278.95.text:
might have silenced the dark-haired girl if
only he had acted quickly enough: but precisely

11284.16.text:
because of the extremity of his danger he
had lost the power to act. It struck him that

11289.06.text:
in moments of crisis one is never fighting
against an external enemy, but always against

11293.20.text:
one's own body. Even now, in spite of the
gin, the dull ache in his belly made consecutive

11298.93.text:
thought impossible. And it is the same, he
perceived, in all seemingly heroic or tragic

11305.22.text:
situations. On the battlefield, in the torture
chamber, on a sinking ship, the issues that

11310.99.text:
you are fighting for are always forgotten,
because the body swells up until it fills

11315.32.text:
the universe, and even when you are not paralysed
by fright or screaming with pain, life is

11320.49.text:
a moment-to-moment struggle against hunger
or cold or sleeplessness, against a sour stomach

11327.39.text:
He opened the diary. It was important to write
something down. The woman on the telescreen

11334.28.text:
had started a new song. Her voice seemed to
stick into his brain like jagged splinters

11339.11.text:
of glass. He tried to think of O'Brien, for
whom, or to whom, the diary was written, but

11345.03.text:
instead he began thinking of the things that
would happen to him after the Thought Police

11348.03.text:
took him away. It would not matter if they
killed you at once. To be killed was what

11353.36.text:
you expected. But before death (nobody spoke
of such things, yet everybody knew of them)

11358.47.text:
there was the routine of confession that had
to be gone through: the grovelling on the

11362.06.text:
floor and screaming for mercy, the crack of
broken bones, the smashed teeth, and bloody

11368.96.text:
Why did you have to endure it, since the end
was always the same? Why was it not possible

11373.85.text:
to cut a few days or weeks out of your life?
Nobody ever escaped detection, and nobody

11378.81.text:
ever failed to confess. When once you had
succumbed to thoughtcrime it was certain that

11382.94.text:
by a given date you would be dead. Why then
did that horror, which altered nothing, have

11387.85.text: to lie embedded in future time?

11391.34.text:
He tried with a little more success than before
to summon up the image of O'Brien. 'We shall

11396.08.text:
meet in the place where there is no darkness,'
O'Brien had said to him. He knew what it meant,

11401.18.text:
or thought he knew. The place where there
is no darkness was the imagined future, which

11405.84.text:
one would never see, but which, by foreknowledge,
one could mystically share in. But with the

11411.00.text:
voice from the telescreen nagging at his ears
he could not follow the train of thought further.

11415.25.text:
He put a cigarette in his mouth. Half the
tobacco promptly fell out on to his tongue,

11420.25.text:
a bitter dust which was difficult to spit
out again. The face of Big Brother swam into

11425.81.text:
his mind, displacing that of O'Brien. Just
as he had done a few days earlier, he slid

11431.82.text:
a coin out of his pocket and looked at it.
The face gazed up at him, heavy, calm, protecting:

11440.47.text:
but what kind of smile was hidden beneath
the dark moustache? Like a leaden knell the

11448.06.text:
WAR IS PEACE
FREEDOM IS SLAVERY
